75723909.review:
A great addition to the Black Mesa experience.
The amount of additional enemies, weapons and mechanics you find are actually quite impressive, even in 2020. For example, you can climb up ropes here. You can't even do that in Half-Life 2. There are many alien weapons you can directly use, and as this is about as twice as long as Half-Life: Blue Shift, you have a good number of curated combat situations to use them in.

The game is actually quite tough, even on medium difficulty. I had to move through a few situations with save-scumming tactics - but on the whole I found it enjoyable. Thanks to the length there are several interesting story revelations, which I assume are canon. G-Man is a right cheeky bastard in this, too.

Worth your time.

75688813.review:
Although I bought this when I was 10, I didn't get round to it for 20 years. 

I think this game has a really nice level of difficulty. Playing on hard was challenging, but not frustrating apart from the occasional Worms-esque moment when an enemy throws a grenade vertically 15ft through 2 doorways only for it to land perfectly on your face. Clearing a dark warehouse crawling with semi-invisible black ops feels great.  

Not crazy about all of the new weapons, found myself only using the detached Barnacle when absolutely necessary, same goes for the Desert Eagle, and Spore Launcher. Also, while it's not exactly HL's thing, more sniper ammo would've been pretty gosh darn sexy.

It took me about 10 hours to complete on hard, well worth the 99p I paid for it. The only thing that really hindered me was the occasional crashes; at certain points, be they particular rooms or particular corridors if I was using deployable explosives, sometimes the game just crashes. I'd also occasionally get stuck on the landscape, particularly during the kinda fiddley platform sections.  

All in all, there's so much classic HL action to be had here - really solid campaign. The finale is a bit of a damp squib, wet fart of an affair, but still so worth it if like me you sat on it for 2/3rds of your life. 

Oh and a really common criticism of this is that it breaks canon... but... like... so? it's a spin-off! It's good!

Opposing Force starts off strong and seems very promising. But it comes to a screeching halt following a tedious and uninspired boss battle. Opposing Force has so much potential but it all just falls flat. The game clocks in at around 4-6 hours, which is fine for me. I often enjoy short but sweet single player romps.

All in all, I still recommend it. It certainly has its share of problems but I'd still rather play it than literally any recent AAA game. 

I guess I can finally cross this game of my list. It only took me 20 years or so to get to it.

74787101.review:
Second official expansion for Half-Life and definitely worth your time if you enjoyed either Half-Life or the previous expansion Blue Shift. 

After recently playing through all of Half-Life, Blue Shift and Opposing Force for the first time in a few years, I find myself ever so slightly preferring Opposing Force to Blue Shift. It's way more inventive for a start, instead of a flashlight you have night-vision, this isn't only a nice little feature but also crucial when you reach a handful of parts in the game where you're plunged into complete darkness and rely on it to find your way around. There's also a neat new weapon which sits alongside your two melee weapons which is a barnacle you can fire at certain green wall-dwelling creatures to grapple your way across the environment just like the Grappling Hook in the Zelda games! Why this wasn't used again in HL2 I'll never know

As with Blue Shift, Opposing Force takes place alongside the main game Half-Life, only this time instead of playing as our usual silent protagonist Gordon Freeman, you take control of a military dude who is part of the first wave sent in to kill Gordon Freeman. No spoilers but if you have played through the original Half-Life game you'll know that things go very wrong and that even the first wave sent in to "fix the problem" was only the beginning of a huge operation.

Opposing Force isn't very long, obviously your first play will be your longest. I took my time, but when you know exactly what you're supposed to be doing (or you're just very good at these older, cooler FPS games) this game can be done within 60 mins or so. That being said there's plenty of moments which will bring a smile to your face, whether you recently finished HL or not, you'll still recognise some areas or even the exact messages being spoken over the radio transmitters. Oh and you'll also see the mysterious G-Man, who also speaks this time (first time he speaks in the franchise? Not sure, maybe)

Overall a great expansion, I would recommend for the reasons that I've given above, although I would strongly recommend a play of the original game first in order to make the most out of it. Thank's for reading, VVc0w

74739856.review: The game follows the story of Half-Life from the perspective of Adrian Shephard, a 22 year old US Marine Corporal, who was sent alongside his squad to eliminate the alien invaders from the Black Mesa facility. Shephard is led in a fight for his life through the laboratory complex, encountering multiple enemies and reconcilling with team members, being aided by various new weapons specific for his military background. The suspense in this game is one of the elements that make the game be a great memory for the older gamers from the 90's era. One of the greatest expansions ever made.

74649863.review: I give this expansion a 10/10. In my opinion, this is how to make an expansion to an already awesome game. You play as Adrian Shepard, a Marine sent in to contain the Black Mesa incident. The tutorial has you navigating through a boot camp and introduces many of the new mechanics such as rope climbing, how your P.C.V. (Powered Combat Vest) works, and how your night-vision goggles function. This game features many new weapons and tons of new enemies from a completely different planet. Some of the new weapons are the Desert Eagle handgun, a M40A1 Sniper Rifle, and many new "alien" weapons. This game also features new AI squad members, some of which can heal you, open sealed doors or just help out with some extra firepower. The beginning of the game takes place around "Surface Tension" in Half-Life, even showing Gordon Freeman being captured. Many other references to Half-Life's events are cleverly placed. I think that if Valve were to use Adrian Shepard again, he would make an awesome protagonist for another game set in the Half-Life universe. If you're a fan of 90's FPS games and loved Half-Life, this is a must-have for you.

74596927.review:
Excellent expansion to the Half Life universe made by Gearbox Software. 
The game takes you to a different perspective of the Black Mesa incident. Rather than an employee there such a scientist or security guard, you’re in the boots of Alan Shepard, a member of the HECU unit in the USMC tasked with quelling the ongoing incident at Black Mesa. However due to the circumstances at hand when you arrive, you won’t be at odds with the surviving scientists and security guards at Black Mesa, but a whole new group of aliens in addition to the ones encountered in Half Life. In addition to the new enemies, you will be exploring new areas of Black Mesa and will be armed with a new set of weapons, both HECU issue and of out of this world. But in your quest to survive against the alien onslaught in the wake of the resonance cascade, you will also be working with HECU members at times, although despite their wonky ai at times, will prove useful in fighting against enemies while also progressing through the campaign, which isn’t as long as the standard Half Life campaign but is still long enough to leave the player satisfied. 

The puzzles and level difficulty is on par with Half Life but the scenery and enemies will be different. The tutorial mission isn’t in Black Mesa but instead at boot camp/training, which explores new game functions and mechanics while also showcasing much of the new weapons in the game. There is multiplayer as well but it’s not the main selling point of the game and the player base for it is low and gameplay is lacking compared to other standalone Gold Source multiplayer titles like Team Fortress:Classic, Half Life: Death Match, Day of Defeat, and Sven Co-Op. But in the event of downloading Opposing Force, the multiplayer  is still worth checking out. Overall, Half Life Opposing Force is a great expansion to the universe and a great game as well. I’ll leave the story for you to explore. It’s worthy of its praise but keep in mind it’s still over 20 years old.
I recommend.

74590364.review:
The people who say this is better than Half-Life are on crack. It's what many expansions are; a mini version of the base game, condensed and less ambitious, but the same formula. It is more Half-Life, not better Half-Life. It does have a bit of a different style which is refreshing, as you play as a Marine in an overdone comedic gung ho style.

You revisit parts of Black Mesa seen in Half-Life, but you will see different parts of these locations. The level design doesn't bring anything new to the table, although the final maze-like encounter with black ops enemies is one of the best combat encounters in the series. 

The "puzzle" gameplay (solving practical problems to navigate the environment) is less clever than in Half-Life, which wasn't outstanding in this regard either. But Opposing Force is more focused on combat where it does present more challenge than Half-Life especially due to some of its new enemy types, but for the most part more forgettable levels. 

After all, Half-Life never excelled in gameplay, rather it excelled in presentation, and the presentation and general structure of Opposing Force has less memorable moments. Opposing Force also has a new set of weapons placed in rather lazy but logical places, and like Half-Life a number of these weapons are never ideal to use in any situation, therefore this lacks the intelligent weapon design seen in games like Doom, Quake, and Unreal most of all. 

[h3]Strengths[/h3]
[list]
[*]Amusing over the top gung ho marine style, Opposing Force has character

[*]Decent new enemy types that pose a greater combat challenge

[*]Some cool tie-ins with the original game

[*]A few new types of combat encounters, particularly more maze-like ones that sometimes use pitch darkness against you to encourage night vision use (the game had to make use of the new night vision goggles after all)

[*]Fairly interactive world like in the original game

[*]The Desert Eagle with laser sight is a cool new weapon
[/list]

[h3]Weaknesses[/h3]
[list]
[*]Once again many of the weapons are never ideal for any situation, the creativity and intelligence behind weapon design isn't great (a flaw shared by the base game)

[*]Friendly AI that you can command is very dumb

[*]Only 2 channel audio ever since Valve broke it years ago

[*]The "puzzle" gameplay (practically getting past environmental obstacles) is rather uninspired and lacks creativity, a downgrade over the base game in this regard which already wasn't the most intelligent here

[*]Hardly any secrets on any level

[*]Encourages cover shooting at times despite not having leaning or iron sights, although it does this less often than the base game

[*]Final boss is one of the lamest and laziest I've ever seen in a game

[*]Features Half-Life's overly slidey movement that lacks precision, not the best feeling FPS game
[/list]

Overall it's decent, but you're honestly not missing much by not playing this. It is a combat focused FPS without the best gameplay design in any area.

74380174.review:
Opposing Force is a really interesting beast. Despite being an expansion to Half-Life, it plays almost nothing like it. I mean, sure, it has a pretty decent blend of story and gameplay much like Half-Life, but it's much more combat-focused. You play as a soldier this time around, right down to training at boot camp if you pick the training level, and you get access to a ton of cool new weapons as the game progresses, plus Gearbox added a new batch of aliens called Race X that complement a more traditional first-person shooter kind of gameplay.

The game's a bit lighter on puzzles than Half-Life, and I recall there being a lot less platforming, but it still has plenty of cool ideas to keep it fresh including a grappling hook mechanic, a displacer cannon that can be used as a one-shot kill or to teleport you to a small Xen location where you might get health and ammunition, new types of companions that give you certain benefits, and even replacing the flashlight with night vision. None of these ideas are implemented [i]perfectly[/i], but they totally change the way that Half-Life plays in the right way.

I have a few complaints about the game as-is, such as how the new rope-swinging mechanic is fiddly and feels out-of-place, and the game's habit of throwing tanky monsters at you ad nauseum, but for me it was a pretty solid four out of five experience through and through, and more than worth the five dollars Valve is asking for it. If you're a Half-Life fan, and you don't give this game a try, you're doing yourself a disservice.

The only game that every comes even close to being the best expansion pack (or DLCs as we call them now) has to be Crysis: Warhead. It's a shame that 21 years later, people aren't pull off what Opposing force did - improve upon the OG game in every possible way.

- Write it so well that you start to 'symphatize' with the enemy? Done.
- More and better guns? Done
- More ways and strategies to kill enemies? Done
- More types of enemies that are actually unique and not the ctrl+C , ctrl+V of old enemies with a new model and new name? done
- Expanding the lore and deeping the already dark mystery? done
- More Xen? done
- More Otis? done

Also, of all the 'boot camp' levels in military shooter games I've ever played, this one takes the cake easily. The closest would be the Soviet level in COD2 where the instructor komissar makes us grenade practice with a potato because 'real grenades are worth more than you' lmao.

The new weapons are unique and a lot of fun to use when compared to the original Half - Life and it's roster of weapons. Your soldier buddies are a great addition and have actual use, unlike the scientists of Black Mesa and the pea-shooter security guards.

My only criticism of this near - perfection of a video game is that the final boss is one of the most underwhelming things I've ever fought, not to mention incredibly easy, even on Hard.

73671199.review:
Opposing Force is an excellent expansion for an excellent game, and, given its low price, is a recommended purchase for anyone who liked Half-Life. The opposite is also true: if you didn't like the first game, there's nothing in this package that will change your mind.

The game follows mostly the same steps as the original, telling the story from the point of view of one of the soldiers who was sent to capture Gordon Freeman. Both narratives happen in parallel, and if you played Half-Life before you will better enjoy the events seen from a different perspective, although it's possible to do so without having finished Half-Life before.

The game is shorter, about a third or half the original. There are some new enemies and weapons that keep things fresh. Jumping puzzles are not as frequent or as frustrating as the original, and rope mechanics, having been so criticized by many, do not interfere with gameplay at all. In fact, the game ends up being even more fluid than the original.

Opposing Force is a good example of what an expansion should look like, increasing the content of the original game, adding things that renew the gameplay and reducing the size of the campaign so that it doesn't get tiring.

73668737.review: Despite the many problems later in the game with the absolute ungodly amounts of annoying enemies (the sewer area, etc.), the game's additions are for the most part nice and and the overall game is fun. It's another half life campaign of about the same length with two bosses, new weapons, and new npcs. A lot of the weapons are more or less just neat replacements for the original half life weapons, but there's a multiplayer mode that admittedly I haven't tried which has both sets available for use. And the weapons are fun to use so it's fine I guess. If you really like half life, you'll enjoy this. I think the only other bad thing I can say other than the new enemies being spammed late game and pretty much ONLY those enemies, is that they tried to make ropes that you can climb and swing off of, but it's pretty jank.

73407051.review:
[h1]Half-Life: Opposing Force - хорошее начало, душный конец[/h1]

[b]О самой игре Half-Life я всё сказала в обзоре на неё саму,[/b] что касается данного дополнения, то Opposing Force первые впечатления оставил сугубо положительные, а вот под конец играть в него было слегка... малоприятно.

- Новые локации. Они интересные, не уступают оригиналу по красочности, хотя запомнились в итоге хуже, чем локи из Blue Shift. Мапдизайн первую половину игры тащит, как и оригинал, но ближе к концу всё превращается в узкую кишку на каком-нибудь складе, где полезным оружием может быть только шотган, т.к. взрывчаткой можно убить себя, а с автоматикой перестреливаться себе дороже.

- Новое оружие. Что-то отдалённо похожее на дигл - чуть слабее револьвера, но быстрее перезарядка и стрельба, удобно. Снайперская винтовка - улучшенный арбалет (хитскан) и многое другое. Новое человеческое оружие действительно полезно, в основном тем, что банально мощнее. Инопланетные же пушки вообще успеха не снискали. [spoiler]Также нам дадут настоящего барнакла, с помощью которого можно цепляться за определённые точки на стенах, но таких мест в игре от силы 3-4...[/spoiler] Всё это обилие оружия занимает у вас кнопки от 1 до 7 на клавиатуре, причём они расположены настолько в хаотическом порядке, что непонятно, почему снайперку и пулемёт нельзя засунуть на 4 к базуке. Посреди замеса пытаться переключаться между оружием очень неудобно.

- Новые враги. В начале игры вы их не встретите, она будет разгоняться как и оригинал, с хедкрабами, обычными вортигонтами и т.д, и т.п., но где-то начиная со второй трети на вас начнёт сыпаться спецназ в чёрном, латексные женщины, какие-то y6людки Расы Х. Постепенно обычные враги пропадают с поля боя и последнюю треть игры вы встречаете ровно ТРЁХ врагов - спецназ в чёрном, который решетит за доли секунды, серые недовортигонты, которые впитывают невероятно много дамага, ну и вишенкой на торте ОГРОМНЫЕ ЖУЧАРЫ, которые тоже стреляют, а выдерживают по 10 шотов из дробовика. Впервые встретившись с ними, я подумала, что это мини-босс, но нет ;З

[b]По итогу мы имеем игру, которая в начале даёт нам новый интересный контент (да и сюжет тут тоже интересный), но потом сливается в какую-то просто ущербную душноту, где вас насилуют в каждом закоулке одни и те же враги в огромных количествах, а вы в судорожных попытках найти необходимое оружие раз за разом умираете и проклинаете разрабов.

Я бы всё равно посоветовала в неё поиграть, но не залпом как я, а дозируя на несколько вечерков понемногу, чтобы вам это всё не надоело.[/b]
[h1]6,5/10[/h1]

This is my favourite expansion pack for half life. Yeah it's short but remember this is not a separate game, this game is to expand universe of half life. You play as Corporal Adrian Shephard a 22-year oldUS Marine Corporal assigned to the Hazardous Environment Combat Unit from the Santego Military Base, Arizona. He is one of the soldiers sent to the Black Mesa Research Facility to eliminate the Xen invaders. The new enemy types are the race x aliens. I like them but some of them are quite annoying. There are lots of new weapons and every weapon is good, my favourite new weapon is the Saw. The Saw is a Lmg that has lots of fire power but you only get it in the middle of the game. The crossbow has been replaced with an actual sniper rifle. There squad members around Black Mesa and they can help you in lot of things. The engineer can cut through sealed doors or floor grates with his welding torch. The medic can heal you or  other soldiers. You can use the radio to get information where to go. The final boss was easy to me on normal but I don't want to spoiler the ending. 

10/10 -My favourite expansion pack for half life 👍

73089370.review:
Honestly, I like Half-Life: Opposing Force better than the original Half-Life. 
Pros:
- the pacing is better
- the weapons are better (even if the alien weapons were introduced in a lazy - albeit realistic - way)
- ropes and military teammates are a great addition, even if the rope physics is atrocious and the AI of the teammates is sub-par
- the story expanded on the lore of the original Half-Life pretty well 
- Otis is a better NPC than Barney. 
- There were some nice touches - I love that when you use the Xen gun while on Xen (when you first get it) it send you to the tutorial room from the original Half-Life. 
- The boot-camp tutorial level is awesome! If you play it definitely do the tutorial.
Cons:
- the previously mentioned rope physics and teammate AI
- you have to go into the settings to fix the mouse, it's a bit buggy at first
- G-man looks different I think; he looks like Quentin Tarantino tbh

Definitely play this nice expansion if you enjoyed the original Half-Life.

Team play is introduced in combat which changes the way you play in an interesting way, even if its just for some of the game. Additionally, there is a training option in the difficulty selection. 71751676.review:
Fantastic expansion, the new weapons the real shining ovation, decent story addition with a new planetary threat alongside the Xen beasts, good set pieces. If you're look at this, you likely already know that. But there are some seriously jarring issues.

The biggest are the glitches. This isn't some random Steam title, this is a first party Valve Software game, and the fact that you have to jump constantly on elevators not to clip into the floor, and that even the patches aren't a guaranteed fix, to say nothing of vent clipping (forcing a reload and to autosave constantly) is draining and immersion breaking. There is no excuse not to have this fixed. I recommend going into Discussions and reading about all the glitches before playing so you don't wind up saving only to find you're stuck in the floor. 

 Beyond this, on the whole the challenge increase is for the most part appreciated, but OF has the bizarre award of some of the best combat situations and level design in all of Half Life, and also some of the worst. The Sewer section is strange, entirely dark (making levers and buttons hard to find and get used to that migraine inducing green filter...) and will outright require trial and error (with death guaranteed with the enemies you deal with down there in claustrophobic tunnels) as you navigate a maze with nothing but instant kill beasts around every corner until you simply memorize where they are. And the only section I can immediately recall with an INFINITE amount of enemy spawns. 

 It's a petty issue, but I like going for 100% kill runs, and it's a mild annoyance that you cannot do that with this title. To add to that, the game has a ton of meat that unless you're checking walkthroughs you would never know otherwise. For instance, there is a weapon that allows you to teleport to Xen for goodies. 

 Except you can go to new areas every chapter, which is an awesome inclusion. The game never tells you this.  There are conveyance issues, and again, while a GREAT super fun action thrill-ride, the amount of Trial and Error is a bit obnoxious. Not a game breaker, and by all means PLEASE buy and play this expansion, just be aware it's not quite as tight as the main game in regards to stability.

71192348.review:
This expansion has its ups and downs, but the cons heavily outweighed the fun times I had playing this mod.
I love the Half-Life series to death, and this is the only one that I have disliked.
The levels are obscenely difficult, and instead of making it fun to beat such a challenge, they design the enemies to be cheap and annoying to deal with. Don't even get me started on the fucking pit drones.
I played through the campaign in both hard and easy difficulty, and there was absolutely no difference.

The Vortigaunts are placed in ways to ambush the player, but the problem is that they typically damage you when there is nothing you can do about it, since they are either placed in hard-to-kill spots, or you have no ammunition left. There is also a severe lack in medkits during these sections, requiring sv_cheats 1 if you save in a bad spot.

I also had to noclip out of certain floors or walls, because the game is so fucking bad that it lets you get stuck in them.

The final boss was underwhelming as well, and violated the basic rule of the Half-Life series: show a way that you can beat your enemies.
I was stuck on it for a while because HOW THE FUCK AM I SUPPOSED TO KNOW TO SHOOT THE GODDAMN PURPLE BALL?
Throughout the early days of the Half-Life series, balls of energy have been shown to teleport, so I thought that I would have to go in the ball. The game didn't let me.
Then I realized you could shoot out the eyeballs of the alien. Thought that if you shot them out enough times, it would kill it. After about 10 times of shooting out the eyeballs with no change, I realized this wasn't it.

The weapons are also unbalanced. Some guns are weaker than a peashooter, while others are stupidly good. In the end, it doesn't even matter, since you won't have enough ammo to fire these guns in the first place.

Also, who decided to make the Black Ops tanks? You cannot kill them with a FULL SMG MAGAZINE. ON THE EASIEST DIFFICULTY.

That being said, this mod had its moments. During the times when it wasn't obscenely difficult, the campaign was loads of fun to play through. I only recommend this game to the die-hard Half-Life fans, since the only reason I slogged through the frustrating parts of the campaign was to say that I had beaten the whole Half-Life series.

I might play through it another time and edit my review, but for now, I would rather play Hunt Down the Freeman. (Kidding, of course. This expansion wasn't that bad, but it hasn't aged well.)

70909686.review:
Opposing Force is one of the greatest spin-offs of a major title I've experienced to this day. One of my favorite things to do in a video game is play the antagonist, experience the not-so-heroic side of things. This game nails that perfectly. From killing civilians to chasing Gordon Freeman ever-so closely makes this game an incredibly different experience that we've come to enjoy and know from Half-Life.

Another great element was the huge amount of new weapons and enemies that aren't seen in Half-Life. It gives this game it's own personality and really makes it stand out among the other games in the franchise. So many unique elements in this game, things completely exclusive to this game.

One of my least favorite things from Half-Life and Blue Shift were the Xen levels, however. But here, Opposing force did that well, too. You go to Xen for possibly a grand total of 5 minutes in this 6 hour game. It's not that I don't like Xen, it's just the level design in those parts consistently tended to fall apart in those segments.

This game also greatly encourages working with your squad. Whenever they present to you a fellow soldier in the game, shortly after, there will be a series of hostiles that you could take by yourself, but would prove to be a bit tough, even with all the weapons the game gives you, but would prove an absolute cake walk with a team. Which is great, because, this way, you don't feel like an all-powerful God that nothing can stop, instead you just feel like a guy... with bottomless pockets to fit 20 guns.

My only gripe is that at times the level design was a bit questionable. The path forward wasn't always that obvious, and sometimes kind of, well, dumb. It's not often that I feel this, and it's never that bad, it's just... odd at times.

Overall, I give Half-Life: Opposing Force:

9.2 Weaponized Barnacles out of 10

Yeah, the weaponized barnacles might have been one of my favorite weapons. If only we got it sooner in the game, and was given more freedom with it. Fingers crossed Crowbar Collective makes a remake of this game on the same caliber as Black Mesa.

70343078.review:
I must start this review off by saying I am not a huge fan of Half Life despite playing 1, 2 as well as Blue Shift all the way through, however I think they are good games but I found them to be a bit uninspired. So when I played Opposing Force I went in thinking that it would also feel pretty meh but I was quite pleasantly surprised about how good Opposing Force actually is

To start off with the good: The Story is quite interesting as you are put in the shoes of a Marine by the name of Sheppard who is sent with other marines by the U.S Government to eliminate all Black Mesa employees and erase traces of the incident. Along the way you will face off agaisnt many aliens you have come used to in Half Life but later on you also will face off against some other new enemy types which I will not spoil here for those who have not played the game. but they are definitely different and add more flavor to this expansion


This expansion also adds many new weapons to the mix all of which feel great, you now have a wrench and a knife both functioning as melee weapons, Night Vision goggles replacing your flashlight, A Sniper Rifle, A light Machine Gun, An Energy Pulse hand, A Barnacle Hand, A Desert Eagle pistol and more. All of these new weapons add a lot of new layers to the game and make the game feel truly unique and fun to go through.

Another plus is that the level design is more straight forward and simple compared to the mazey and at times quite annoying levels found in the Original Half Life, The levels do have their fair share of puzzles but they are all well done imo and thankfully you have no annoying sections such as On A Rail


This game is also decently long for an expansion, I finished it in 8 hours myself and it felt like the right length, there is also a final boss which is pretty tough.


Overall I feel that this expansion for Half Life 1 really surpasses the Original game in every way and feels like it's own game with all of the new things they crammed into here. Imo it's easily the best game in the Half Life Franchise and if you are a fan of the series you definitely should check this game out, it goes for pretty cheap on steam being only 5 dollars normally and it goes on sale very often so really you should pick it up. You Won't be disappointed

68709628.review: This is a surprisingly long, meaty Half Life adventure, and while not quite as good as the original, it's still excellent. I made the mistake of underestimating it, thinking it was just a throwaway add-on, but it's certainly not. There's a lot of recycling from the first game, obviously, but also many new weapons --some of the best in the franchise-- and new enemy types. And, of course, more of those memorable Half Life moments and set-pieces. If you liked the original, jump straight into this one. It's got a somewhat different vibe: there are fewer large-scale set pieces, more corridor shooting, more difficult gun-play due to the new enemies, and even more puzzle platforming -- which is an acquired taste, but works pretty well here, because the platforming, in general, is less tricky and more straightforward than in the original, more about figuring out the route than landing precise jumps. I played on Hard, though, and I have to say the final third, while still good, dragged on a bit. The fights get harder, bigger, longer, and more frequent, and the bullet-soaking enemies get more numerous. I do think the original switches things up with more panache and sense of pacing. That said, this doesn't mean Opposing Force takes a nosedive or anything like that, and the final boss is definitely an improvement over Half Life's. So please, don't get discouraged and jump on this: it's very, very good.

68350581.review:
Opposing Force provides a comparatively short and enjoyable experience to the base game. While the protagonist, Adrian Shepard, doesn't speak (similarly to Gordon Freeman), I think he exudes as much character just being who and what he is. The plot synopsis is that you, as a H.E.C.U. marine, don't receive your orders to kill the Black Mesa staff, thus being rendered ignorant to the real reason for being deployed there, and must navigate your way across the facility while your mission crumbles around you from the very beginning; I find this to be an interesting perspective on the metaplot, seeing as how the marines were strictly enemies in the base game.

With the exception of the poisonous ball-thing launcher, all of the new weapons are useful and are complementary to the standard weapon selection that carries over from the base game, especially the machine gun: the machine gun has a high rate-of-fire and high damage output, making it one of the most effective weapons that you can get in this expansion.

Periodically, you'll acquire squad members that make certain combat sequences much easier and can be used to move the story forward, like breaking down a steel door you couldn't otherwise get past.

Overall, this comes highly recommended, with the only caveat being that if you didn't like the base game, you probably won't like this.

68113045.review:
Did I enjoy? The game? Yes. Is it worth 5 bucks? Maybe. Is it better than Half Life 1? Defintely not.

I knew that this was originally a DLC, and that it isn't supposed to be long, but 8 hours? This doesn't even reflect the actual time it takes to play this (I am pretty slow when it comes to FPS games, and I also had to load my saves a lot).
This game gives you a new perspective, you are now playing as the "meanie", the one sent to massacre Black Mesa and kill Freeman. I like this new perspective and find it a good addition to the lore of the franchise. 

You get new weapons and new enemies (which are challenging, I have to admit). The weapons are really cool and useful (Also, you get 3 new Alien buddies instead of just one like in the base game).
My favorite part of the game was the first boss, the Pit Worm, mainly because it was just one long puzzle. Yeah I am aware that it's a straight copy of the Tentacles from the main game, but who cares. It made me use my brain.

Other than the fact that it's short, the only thing that made this such a letdown was the ending. Not the cool Gman cutscene, but the final boss. It took me more than an hour to beat a 15 minute boss, mainly because my rockets went through the boss instead of actually hitting it, which made me think that I needed to target other parts of the boss's body instead of the parts that actually take damage. The boss was so boring that I thought that I still had 8 more hours ahead of me, And I was so disappointed when I saw the Gman appearing in front of me and the credits starting to roll by.

Overall, it was a fun revisit to the Half Life world, but it was just hyped too much. I recommend you play it, but don't get your hopes up.

68069081.review:
[h1] Better Than Blue Shift, With A Hint Of Not **** [/h1]

This is the expansion to Half-Life you need. It tells the story of the military sent to clean the alien threat from Black Mesa while eliminating any witnesses. You are Adrian Shephard and you don't actually take part in the "eliminating witnesses" part. Instead, you are a badass soldier who is very much like Gordon Freeman, a one man army with a wopping selection of weapons to choose from. You gain more than Gordon does and each one is creative to a degree and somewhat helpful to traversing the terrain or unleashing hell.

The story is simple, as described, but like Blue Shift, your actions interlock with Gordon's as he is causing chaos around Black mesa. You always seem behind him, but eventually move onto a different path as another bunch of alien races interfere with a war between the US military and Black Mesa itself. There's less of a horror side to this expansion, as you feel more like Marcus Fenix, feeling almost bulletproof. It's a blast playing as this soldier, there's so many more enemies to blow away and more varied ways to eliminate them. Overall though, it's more Half-Life with some great additions, even if it can feel a bit much at times.

That's a lie. This game ramps up in difficulty at some point. The new aliens are there to push you against a corner and the Black Op soldiers punish your ammo. You'll see less standard, recognisable enemies. They are nothing to your arsenal. The difficulty is welcome at times but other times the AI is too quick to react to your movement and they will fire first when you turn a corner. 

Besides that, the only other negative I have is how there's less dialogue. You don't have scientists telling you what's happening or what you're meant to be doing at times. I got stuck in an elevator shaft with hanging sparking wires indicating danger. I didn't know I had to climb the safe rope to get higher as I saw a welcoming path at a lower level and so there I spent a while walking in circles wondering where to go next. Who would think a rope would be climbable in a Half-Life game, especially when it looks just like the sparking wires next to it.

But yes, this game is great and offers a good side story with about 3 hours worth of gameplay if you take it slow. It's worth replaying to pick up on the details that link to the core game but yeah, get when it's on sale and have fun slaughtering aliens.

You play as the "opposing force" from the original game: the military. This provides a completely unique viewpoint of the Resonance Cascade. Easy recommend. Play this after Blue Shift, if you even bought that in the first place.

This slice of the Half-Life story felt very complete, definitely worth playing through if you're already going to play the original Half-Life. The game follows the original plot from the perspective of the forces opposing Gordon Freeman and the Black Mesa scientists. 

As DLC to Half-Life, this is just more of an already good game and more than worthy of being its owning expansion. It bring the same fun gameplay and challenges to the table while offering the base game's story from a different perspective. Campaign is about half as long as the base game, well worth the time.

67149277.review:
[h1]Quick Summary[/h1]
Half-Life: Opposing Force is overall a good expansion to the original Half-Life game. Obviously it's recommended that you play Half-Life before playing this expansion. New weapons and monsters are introduced as you fight your way through Black Mesa during the incident infamously started by Gordon Freeman. Of course, the game is old and doesn't hold up graphically, but the gameplay is still pretty tight. It feels more like a corridor shoot-em-up than a continuation of any story, as it's told from a different perspective of an event we already know about.

[h1]My Full Review[/h1]
I recommend this game overall to any active or soon to be Half-Life fans. If you're looking to learn something new about the story, this isn't it. This expansion is more dedicated to the gun play than anything else. The puzzles aren't too hard to figure out, and the environments aren't anything you haven't really seen in Half-Life. The encounters are quite brutal and a lot of trial and error is involved.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
There are plenty of new weapons to use as you make your way through the game. With more weapons comes a LOT of enemies per level. You'll spend a lot of time using cover and peeking to get shots off on some of the tough enemies, as they tend to sponge a lot of damage and hit hard.

Puzzles are present, however they aren't too difficult. I suggest learning how to crouch jump if you're not familiar, because there are a lot of areas that assume you'd know how to do this. There are some sections that aren't immediately obvious as to what you should do either, so keep an eye on all of your options on how to traverse a situation.

The game is obviously old and you'll notice parts that are rough around the edges, most notably when interacting with ropes, the grapple hook, physics interactions, and the AI. My biggest issue was the boss fight. After fighting your way to the end, the boss fight is laughably easy and kind of boring.

[h1]Story / Plot[/h1]
You're playing in the perspective of Adrian Shepard, a US Marine Corporal who's assigned to the Hazardous Environment Combat Unit. You don't receive the full briefing of your upcoming mission and end up running through Black Mesa during the infamous incident started by Gordon Freeman from Half-Life.

The gameplay doesn't translate to the story very well, as it's as simple as, "Adrian fights his way out of Black Mesa." You'll see plenty of easter eggs and nods to the first Half-Life to help indicate the timeline of events. Otherwise, there's not much to say about this game for the story. You'll be playing Half-Life: Opposing Force for the gameplay more than anything. If you're not interested in more Half-Life gameplay as much as more story, I suggest just looking up a synopsis on YouTube.

[h1]Graphics / Audio[/h1]
For a game initially released in 1999, it's understandable that the graphics and audio aren't going to hold up to standards found in 2020. With that aside, the graphics are still quite interesting as they were in Half-Life. I did find it pretty obvious as to which assets were added in Half-Life: Opposing Force, because they had a different feel about them that didn't quite match Half-Life in some ways. The graphics overall hold a fantastic grungy sci-fi aesthetic and work perfectly for the game.

The audio is... not good. It absolutely doesn't hold up in any way. The sounds are definitely nostalgic and worked well for the time, but the voices sound strangely robotic and the guns are obnoxious. There's also a moment towards the end in a storage facility where boxes are moving on a rail, and the sound gets so loud that all other sounds distorted unpleasantly. Audio isn't the strong suit in this game, or any of the original Half-Life games.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Pick this game up if you really enjoyed the gameplay found in Half-Life. If you're looking for additional story material, there's not much here that warrants the playtime. Expect the old age of this game to provide some rough moments, but take time to appreciate the craft of the past. Half-Life was no easy feat, and even today, it still shows.

[h1]Please Rate This Review[/h1]
I spend a lot of time breaking down game design and development from a critical consumer's perspective. If you've read all the way through, please give it a rating. The feedback helps!

One of two expansion packs for the original Half-Life (the other being Blue Shift; we don't count Decay, as it's a PS2 "game" and the PC Illuminati have no time for the console ignorami [redundant, I know]) by Gearbox, Opposing Force is the better of the two.  My main reason for saying so is the presence of new weapons in the game, including a handful of alien weapons, several of which make the gameplay much more interesting.  

Otherwise, the game is very similar to Half-Life; you work your way through a messed up situation, both indoors and outdoors, fight aliens and humans, and try to survive.  Sure, you now work with Marines to bust down doors, but that's a pretty small thing.  Much like Blast Pit in the original, you kill a big monster by going to opposite ends of the level to activate switches.  

If you like the original, I can't see much of a reason not to play this one.  Good stuff.

66705266.review:
If you enjoyed Halflife 1, get this game. 

This expansion is full of new mechanics and what makes this great is that it tries to be different to Halflife 1. The guards are different, the guns are different, the flashlight is different, even the zombies look different. What truly differentiates it is its focus. This game has a story of course, but it's a progression is a lot more focused on harder combat, a lot more platforming and a lot more utilising of NPCs; it's less lever turning or sequence solving than what there was in Halflife 1. It's a different experience, but it still feels like Halflife 1 and is still fun to play, Corporal Shepherd is also a cool character and he has some pretty cool interactions Gordon Freeman never managed to have. The stories of Halflife 1 and Opposing Force aren't just completely isolated either, there's plenty of brilliant crossovers between both.

I will say, however, that while the ending was cool, the final sort of "hurdle" was kind of easy, even on a hard difficulty, but the rest of the game can be very hard, more so than the first as there is a lot less handholding as it expects the player to already to be accustomed to Halflife.

65950685.review:
This expansion is basically Hunt Down the Freeman but released 20 years earlier.

There are some things this game nails, mainly in terms of game mechanics, such as adding climbable ropes or slightly expanding the squad system. There are also interesting new weapon concepts. Also the boot camp tutorial is extremely well done, and it's probably the highlight of the game.

Unfortunately for the expansion, all the new concepts are very poorly integrated. For example, climbable ropes appear maybe 2 or 3 times throughout the entire game. In another case, 2 new types of suit rechargers are teased in the tutorial, military and civilian, and I only saw the military recharger once (I didn't find a single civilian recharger).

Health and suit power pickups are very scarce, and you are often thrown into hordes of enemies. There's one section where you're in a pitch-black maze and are meant to face off against many miniboss-tier enemies, with no ammo or health pickups. On the very last level, you face off against hordes of black-ops, at which point i turned on noclip and godmode because I was tired of this.

At one point, multiple new weapons are introduced very close to each other, with little instructions on how to use them, so I finished the game with about 3 weapons I ended up never using. 

These complaints are just a very small slice of annoyances I had with the expansion. However, I don't feel like writing, so I'll stop here.

Blue shift is a much better expansion, go play that instead.

65117534.review:
Now, I know this is going to get me hate, I get it, we're all Half-Life fans here, but please, hear me out on this one, I have a lot of bases to cover.
To start off, let's just do a quick pros and cons for Opposing Force:
Pros:
New, completely original soundtrack by Chris Jensen
Campaign that is longer than the original Half-Life's
New weapons, characters, enemies, and multiplayer gamemodes to explore
Cons:
gameplay seems incredibly unbalanced in some areas
cool concepts (the xen portal gun) are left relatively unexplored
Bugs, a LOT of bugs.

This brings me to the main reason why I am not recommending Opposing Force right now. The game has unfortunately aged abysmally. Originally, I had thought that my issues were coming from the fact that I was playing on Hard mode. Lord knows "Hard" meant something different in the 90s than it does now, but the further in I went, the more I realized that it wasn't me, it was the game. Weapons that I had picked up and appeared in my hotbar failed to actually register as weapons I had. This was a major problem for several portions of the game, as my rocket launcher, xen portal gun, and machine gun were all effectively missing from my inventory despite the fact that I had them and ammo for them. The second major issue I had was an unavoidable crash near the end of the game. In the parking garage, I would crash every single time I attempted to turn a corner down a ramp, effectively forcing me to use cheats just to finish the game.
Next off, the gameplay itself, while being Half-Lifey, is honestly broken in its own right. Enemies appear to be able to damage the player more than the player can damage them with the same weapon when playing on Hard mode. I know I'm going to be told to just "get good" over this, but a fundamental element of singleplayer, story driven games is that the player feels like their in control. Sure, for things like giant aliens, I can see the reasoning behind why I'm not stronger than them, but Adrian Shephard isn't supposed to be a regular soldier, either, he's supposed to be a Corporal that's equipped with a new, experimental suit of armor akin to the soldier version of the HEV suit. Attacks from Shock Troopers take a minimum of 10 hp off Adrian if he doesn't have any suit power, and believe me, suit power is few and far between in this game. Things like the rope gameplay and use of a night vision instead of flashlight seem arbitrary and unnecessary to me. The rope gameplay itself seems to fail to do its job properly in every place it's in during gameplay, especially during the final boss. Night Vision, on the other hand, is weak and doesn't go out far enough for the player to see in some dark areas of the game where it's an absolute necessity.


[h1] SPOILERS FOR THE STORY BELOW [/h1] 

Opposing Force sees you as Corporal Adrian Shephard, an HECU Commander equipped with an experimental Military vest called the "PCV" or "Powered Combat Vest." Shephard and his squad are brought in early on during the Black Mesa incident, but Shephard is knocked out after their heli crashes. Because of this, you witness the end of Half-Life early on in the campaign, and see what happens after Gordon has already defeated the Nihilinth afterwards. After initial containment by the HECU is deemed a failure, the black ops are brought in to take out everyone through the use of a warhead. Shephard disarms the warhead, but it later detonates after the end of the game anyway. After fighting through hoards of Race X aliens and Black ops, Shephard finds himself in the depths of the industrial section of Black Mesa. Here, he encounters the Gene Worm, a giant Race X alien capable of processing and converting the entire planet into a habitat fit for Race X. Shephard kills it and is captured by the Gman, who keeps him in stasis, leaving the player to wonder what might happen to him next.

The story and gameplay tell a very different tale than that of Half-Life. You're not a super scientist saving the world in a big orange suit, you're a soldier on the losing side of a war fighting desperately to survive, knowing that the only way to win is to sacrifice Black Mesa and everyone in it. Opposing Force feels a lot like the Halo Reach of Half-Life. You don't feel anywhere near as Strong as Gordon Freeman, and you have to abandon and sacrifice your own squad members throughout the campaign just to keep going. With Opposing Force starting near the end of Half-Life, you can get a proper perspective of what's going on with the invasion outside of Gordon Freeman's point of view, and just how much damage is being dealt to the whole world. By the time you're fighting the gene worm, you don't feel like a hero, you feel like a tired soldier moments away from falling apart, just wanting it all to be over with. When the game ends, after the credit sequence, you aren't booted out into the main menu, you're given a black screen with the low whistling of wind, continuing on into eternity. The game's story is poetic, it puts you in the shoes of a member of the bad guys suffering the same fate as the good guys, and ends with an immense loss, especially considering what happens to humanity next. One can argue that Gordon Freeman's battle in Half-Life is the same, struggling to fight the oncoming invasion and somewhat losing at the end, but in Half-Life, you know what you did saved the world from the Xen invasion, whereas in Opposing Force, you don't have any orders being given to you by scientists or commanders, you're a lost soldier just doing what he can do to survive.

STORY SPOILERS END HERE.

With a story like that, usually I could give a raving 5 star review, but the gameplay is just too broken in the modern day for me to grace it with such. I would say "I hope Valve or Gearbox go back to fix these" but we both know they won't. It's 2020. With all that said and done, though, here's to Half-Life Alyx coming out in just a few days, and here's to Tripmine Studios for their Operation: Black Mesa and Guard Duty mods that they're developing!

The other big Half Life expansion next to Blue Shift, Opposing Force shakes things up by having you play through the events of the original game (again) as one of the enemy soldiers. 65094380.review: Since the beginning of Half-Life, ethics and values have played a role in shaping characters and the situations they find themselves in. In Half-Life: Opposing Force, this idea is central to the perspective you experience. Playing as U.S. Marine Adrian Shephard reveals both the motivations and struggles of a soldier who is committed to their orders, but who also faces the dilemma of questioning who the real enemy is. This interplay of internal conflict is fascinating and strengthens your interactions with scientists, security guards, and even a black operations unit. Of course, the G-Man also makes his appearance throughout, unfolding more mystery while revealing some answers to the timeline from the original game. If you are looking for an expansion to the original Half-Life series that brings insight and broadens the story, look no further. Game on.

64836629.review:
I always considered this [b]Half-Life[/b] expansion to be underrated. I mean, officially authorized third-party expansions are rarely good. But what we have here? It's a pretty neat exception. Sure, [b]Gearbox[/b] (yes, the same [b]Gearbox[/b], which co-founder calls [b]Steam[/b] “[i]dying store[/i]” nowadays) didn't make the [b]Opposing Force[/b] from scratch, but they also didn't just give us more of the same. They seriously tried to create a new experience. And succeeded. A lot.

The idea to let us see the original [b]Half-Life[/b] events from a different point of view alone was kind of brilliant. In [b]Opposing Force[/b] we're playing as [b]Adrian Shephard[/b], a young US Marine Corporal, who was just assigned to the [b]Hazardous Environment Combat Unit[/b] from the [b]Santego Military Base[/b]. In other words, we'll control one of those guys who tried to hunt down [b]Gordon Freeman[/b] for more than a half of the original [b]Half-Life[/b] (that's a lot of halves for one sentence, huh?). We'll do the proper military training, we'll learn more about how things work between the marines and the [b]Black Ops[/b], we'll see how some orders from the original [b]Half-Life[/b] were given (“[i]Forget about [b]Freeman[/b][/i]!”), we'll actually see some events from the original game as different character, etc, etc, etc. Even though there won't be any choice at the end of this expansion, it's still a pretty neat stuff for all [b]Half-Life[/b] fans.

And gameplay-wise? It's also pretty cool. Sure, level design became a little bit more dumb, but it's not nearly as dumb as in some other games [b]Gearbox[/b] will produce after this, and it's also less rough than in the original game. Which is a good thing, since some parts in [b]Valve[/b]'s game were just... [i]UGH![/i] It's kind of sad that the best parts of level design here are copy / pasted from [b]Valve[/b]'s work, but still, I can't say that levels in the [b]Opposing Force[/b] are bad. Quite the opposite, most of the time I totally enjoyed them.

The best thing about gameplay, though, is that there's heck of a lot of the new features here. [b]Gearbox[/b] didn't just change the point of view, they gave us the proper military experience here. We've got quite a lot of new weapons (from regular ones, like sniper rifle and combat knife, to alien), we've got laser sight, we've got the ability to use ropes, we've got night vision, we've got medics and engineers to command (medics can heal both you and nearby [b]NPC[/b]s, while engineers will help you to force open closed doors) and, the best of all, we'll be able to use [b]Barnacle[/b] (one of those things that live on ceilings) as a tool. Remember hookshot from [b]The Legend of Zelda[/b] games? That's pretty much what we've got here. For real. [b]Gearbox[/b] literally added the hookshot to [b]Half-Life[/b]. [i]BOOM![/i] Mind blown.

So, yes, I do recommend this expansion and I do hope it'll get more attention nowadays. I mean, come on! The original [b]Half-Life[/b] still has a life (now it's a sentence with too much “life”...). It got [b]Source[/b] remaster, it got awesome remake called [b]Black Mesa[/b] (go check it out), etc, etc, etc. But [b]Gerbox[/b]'s expansions? Those just stayed in the past. Even though there's a lot of great and unique stuff in them. The [b]Opposing Force[/b] is more than just the expansion. It's a whole new experience. And it doesn't deserve becoming obsolete. [b]21[/b] year later, I totally enjoyed re-playing it. Hope you'll do to. Dixi.

64369145.review:
Half-Life: Opposing Force is a game made by Valve where you play as Adrian Shephard, a Hazardous Environment Combat Unit (HECU) that plays within the same timeframe of the gameplay of the original [i]Half-Life[/i].

(Spoiler from Half-Life) [s]Adrian gets his mission started to get Morgan Freeman.[/s] Adrian will encounter lots of enemies along the way, such as many of the similar types of aliens you encounter from Half-Life, some newer aliens, as well as the Black Ops. You will interact with the scientists and other HECU units to help you along the way as they assist you in progressing through the game. You get to do a few extra things in this game, such as climb and swing from ropes, get some new weapons, and you'll listen into HECU radios that will inform you about your mission and the progress of the alien invasion.

The visuals seem to run off the same engine as the original Half-Life (not surprising) as well as many of the audio tracks and sound effects are very nostalgic.

I like how Valve was able to give us a different viewpoint of the alien invasion from Half-Life, but change it up from the original game. I think this game does a good job of portraying what the HECU would've been doing during the alien invasion at Black Mesa and they did it pretty well. The only underwhelming thing I think this game suffers from is the final boss, which isn't very difficult once you get the rhythm down (like most games). Anyway, I would recommend this game to not only complete your Valve collection, but to also enjoy Half-Life in a new viewpoint.

It builds a more complete picture of the events that unfolded at Black Mesa, as well as building a solid foundation for future releases in this series. Many new weapons and enemies are introduced with an emphasis on those of alien origin.

64358694.review:
Of the two major Half-Life expansion packs, Opposing Force is definitely my favourite partly because it feels more expanded than Blue Shift since you have new enemies, new weapons, the capacity to build a squad and additional means of traversing environments, none of which you have with the latter. One aspect of Op For that I really appreciated was that my expectations of the game's objectives were subverted considerably in a way that makes the HECU almost sympathetic. 
Gameplay is very much familiar with only the new methods of getting around levels - namely rope climbing and using the Barnacles to pull you across - being the newest learning curve but both are pretty straightforward. The new weapons are pretty good and as with Half-Life titles, you have to be strategic with the weapons you use as ammo is pretty scarce though you can use the Displacer Cannon to transport to Xen to find new ammo for most weapon types though you need a large quantity of depleted uranium ammo in the first place to make the transport. Building a squad in the game with other HECU marines is a really nice feature (revolutionary when Op For was first released) where you can order more heavily armed marines with the SAW to cover you while the medics could help give a health boost out on the field and engineers can cut through doors. Sometimes they're not essential but there are occasions where it is not possible to progress throughout the game without their help so it is in your best interests to keep safeguard your squad.
In terms of the new Race X aliens, you often have to take a stance using cover and strafing much more than other Half-Life titles as the Shock Troopers have significant offensive strength and the Pit Drones have strength in numbers whilst the Voltigores are ammo sponges that can be deadly in close quarters, where you will often find them.
As much as I enjoyed Blue Shift, Op For is by far the better game to me, also helped by the latter taking a couple of hours longer to complete in addition to the new content available whilst the former is more about creating exposition that sets up Half-Life 2. The biggest criticism I have of Op For is an unresolved bug where you become stuck in position, most frequently so when you travel down an elevator, only being able to look around and forcing you to reload from a point before you got in the elevator. The only resolution I've found is to keep jumping in the elevator until it stops moving so you don't get stuck.

If you got any respect for the Half-Life franchise at all, take a huge step around this one. The GoldSource engine didn't age well, but where the original Half-Life game is carrying its dated environment with a certain sense of retro-nostalgic pride, Opposing Force at best shows how easy it is to fail the test of time.

I don't have enough toes and fingers to count in one gesture how many times I had to reload a quick save not due to challenge, but from getting stuck in elevators or cliffs from climbing up the god-awful ropes. Half the weapons in this game are forgettable and have no reason to be there other than some person at the dev conference brainstorming as much garbage as possible.

The only redeeming factor about this game at all is the ending, so do yourself a favor and watch a walkthrough on YouTube or something – you most certainly won't miss anything of importance.

64190200.review:
One of my fave entries in the Half-Life series. It took the fun bits from the first HL and condensed it into an action-packed game. Some puzzles are copy-pasted from the first game, and a few of the new alien designs are uninspired, but it largely does away with miles of headcrab-stuffed vents and going through three rooms to search for the odd valve or lever to interact with. I think it's definitely worth a try especially if you liked the first game.

The story is told through the perspective of a Marine grunt and it's been handled pretty well, by my estimate at least. It manages to clear up the aftermath of the Black Mesa incident and prepares ground for the events of HL2. Shephard is a bona fide badass and I hope to see him return in a future game.

63067934.review:
Now, this I can get behind. When people say this is one of the best expansions ever made, they're not joking.

I didn't really like the original base game of Half-Life despite its innovations and advancements, because the frustrating bits completely ruined the immersion and experience for me. But Opposing Force has very little if not zero frustrating parts, and is overall much more enjoyable.

Opposing Force is incredibly immersive, and I actually felt the tension and connection to our silent protagonist the whole time. I think the story here is told in a much better way than the base game, but to properly enjoy it, you must have played the original game first.

Well, there's not much to say here, it's more Half-Life, with less frustrating bits and more refined good parts. You can do a lot more here, actually; there's lots of new weapons to use, lots of new enemies to fight, and you can even command allied squads sometimes! The level design here is great, with tons of areas where you have to actually think to progress, but not as difficult and frustrating as Half-Life. The night vision feature is also pretty cool and useful.

It's hard to say much about this game without spoiling it, so I'll just end this by saying I heavily reccomend it and you should definitely play it, whether you liked the original Half-Life or not.

62404373.review:
[u]Half Life: Opposing Force[/u] is, like Half Life: Blue Shift, another spin-off of the famous video game Half Life.

This time, you will embark on the adventures of Corporal [u]Adrian Shepard[/u], a brave soldier from the American military, who, initially charged with capturing Gordon Freeman, will find himself having to cancel the mission and do the only more sensible thing: run away from Black Mesa at all costs!
With the help of the survivors of Black Mesa and his military companions, he will face the looming alien threat and the mysterious "agents in black", who also seem willing to hunt Gordon Freeman and eliminate anyone who dares to escape from Black Mesa.

The game proves much longer and richer in content (in fact you will be able to use many military weapons including the Desert Eagle which is a variant of the revolver, the LMG, the sniper rifle, the C4, the anti-personnel mine with laser sensor, the rocket-launcher with laser aiming system to guide missiles and even alien weapons, very useful when you run out of ammunition) and full of action compared to Half Life: Blue Shift (there are many types of aliens and zombies to face and there are the agents in black who are very tough).

The story may be trivial, but actually, like Half Life: Blue Shift, the game is another important part of the Half Life story.
In fact, through Shepard's eyes, you will be able to discover some parts of the Half Life story (for example the powerful explosion in Black Mesa, which occurred because of a bomb brought by the agents in black and tampered with by the mysterious Gman).
Well yes, even in this game you will be able to meet Gman for more than once, who will sometimes try to help you and in other times he will try to stop you.

Another peculiarity of this game is the possibility of interacting with the characters, especially with the military companions, who will give you support by fighting alongside you (there are the engineer who, equipped with the blowtorch, can open any armored door and the doctor who will provide you with medical treatment).
The problem is their intelligence which is a little bad (they tend to disperse without reason and at some point they don't follow you, as if they don't see you anymore).

The game is a lot of fun because it gives you the impression of fulfilling a real military mission and acting like a soldier and above all there are some bosses to be eliminated.

I highly recommend this game.

62212008.review: Fun add-on to the original “Half-Life” that allows the player to experience the events of that game from a new perspective, namely the one of a US marine that is sent to Black Mesa on a mission that goes instantly wrong. Instead of simply rehashing elements of the main release, “Opposing Force” also introduces new areas, weapons and NPCs and expands on other aspects such as the team fighting mechanics and boss fights. At the same time, it still remains loyal to the original game’s immersive gameplay as well as that mix of action interspersed with puzzles. In 2020, “Opposing Force” looks about as dated as the original game does, and therefore may not be for everyone, but it does provide a few more hours of entertaining playtime in the “Half-Life” universe.

A really well made expansion for an already amazing well known title that is Half-Life. This expansion focuses on Adrian Shepherd, a HECU Corporal and his journey through Black Mesa to eliminate Gordon Freeman. Although it is shorter than base game (4-5 hours average for first timers) it still packs enough content to satisfy your thirst for more Half-Life gameplay and plot. 

Pros:-
->Whole new arsenal of weapons as well as returning ones from original Half-Life.
->Really good side-story.
->New Levels.
->New Enemies and mutated forms (including some previous ones)
->A new way to maneuver the map.
->2 Boss battles.
->Everything else that was good about Half-Life

Cons:-
->Annoying Bugs
->A (kind of) Linear way to defeat final boss, rendering already acquired weapons not of much use.
->Overused enemies towards the end (laser/plasma bolts shooting aliens).
->Mouse Flicker issue (check the guides for a fix).
->Questionable friendly A.I.

Highly recommended for any Half-Life fans out there. It is not recommended to play this before completing original Half-Life or Black Mesa.

61313207.review:
★★★★★ Superb!

[h1]Action[/h1]

A great expansion that manages to hold on it's own without leaning too much on the already successful Half-Life. Gives you a new story line, perfectly supplements the events in Half-Life and throws in some new things that offer a different experience.

Instead of being the protagonist Gordon Freeman, you now take place as an antagonist known as Adrian Shepard, a soldier tasked with hunting down Gordon Freeman while fending of aliens at the same time. It soon turns out that in general chaos everyone fights everyone, including new alien species and black ops soldiers. The story is fantastic, showing a different perspective.

There are a few new weapons (alien lightning gun, Desert Eagle) and some new features. You get to lead other soldiers with various specialties: engineer who can cut doors, medic who can heal you. You learn to climb ropes and at one point you can use alien technology of grappling gun.

Graphics is not great, but it's cool enough and the level design with brilliant color schemes and lighting styles makes up for it.

Overall, this game is a splendid masterpiece and I would recommend anyone buying.

59910629.review:
The adventures of a certain HECU Corporal!

Half Life: Opposing Force is a expansion of the original game made by Gearbox, that takes place during the original Half Life. The game features the character Adrian Shepherd, a HECU Corporal, trapped in the Facilty and has to fight his way through the Facility and also defeat the mysterious Race X with a whole bunch of new weapons!

The gameplay is just as solid as the original with the exception of new levels, creatures, and more imporantly new weapons and oh boy the weapons are pretty solid. Each new weapon provides a new way to shoot down the imposing foes as well as some new ways to complete puzzles such as a barnacle to latch on to other surfaces and much much more! If there is a few gripe I could make it would the Nightvision feature that isn't really helpful from its ugly green glow and the annoying difficultly curve near the end where you pretty much have to use the new weapons to defeat them quickly before the defeat you.

Overall, Opposing Force gave us of what the original Half Life did but with brand new features that make the game a new experience all together! But again the only bad things is the late game difficulty and of course the game's age as a FPS, however, I still enjoyed my time playing at a HECU.

And then Adrian Shepherd was never heard from again.

59693958.review:
"Half Life: Opposing Force" is an unnecessary yet welcome expansion pack that only adds to the original "Half-Life" experience.

I was surprised that I enjoyed this expansion pack as much as I did. For a product made by an entirely different studio, it was still a great experience, although obviously not on par with the original's groundbreaking journey. There are times where it will feel like the four hours it takes to beat the game is wearing thin, but this is usually not the case, as most of the time you will have an action-packed adventure pushing you to forward and excited to see more of what it has to offer. Some battles feel uninspired or ridiculous in the sense that it pits you against multiple incredibly difficult enemies at a time in an attempt to escape the responsibility of creating actually quality fights, but there are more fun battles than not, so it isn't a major issue. A great addition that helps the game feel fresh is the addition of many new enemies, weapons, and character skins. When there are a limited variety of skins for the various non-playable characters you meet, the immersion can kind of be broken, but "Half-Life: Opposing Force"makes sure to add plenty into the mix to avoid that.

The gameplay here is just as great as the original, it feels like an additional side story to the pre-existing game, but with fun, creative changes in certain functions of the world that make for more dynamic gameplay, even if some feel more like gimmicks added just to say they added something new. Nonetheless, this does add a lot to keep it fresh for the few hour run it demands from you, although I found myself playing for about thirty minutes to an hour at most at a time until completing it instead of long stretches of gameplay like for the original, which in comparison would have me glued to the computer for hours just enthralled with what I was playing. This is one of the main differences in quality that puts "Half-Life: Opposing Force" those couple of levels below the original, the replayability here feels much more slim, so there is no doubt I'm more likely to go back and play through "Half-Life" again rather than this expansion pack. This is not to knock the overall experience, just to put a wedge between them quality-wise. 

With all that said, "Half-Life: Opposing Force" is still an excellent experience. Many of the fantastic gameplay mechanics that made the original so great are still here, and you can tell the developers tried their best to live up to Valve's original masterpiece, and the love present here is felt, even if it doesn't hit that almost unreachable mark "Half-Life" set. If you are a "Half-Life" fan, this is an expansion pack you can't go wrong with, as it pumps a breath of fresh air back into the critically acclaimed series and takes a different approach and gives a alternate perspective on the events at Black Mesa.

[RATING: 7.9/10]

59545862.review:
[h1] Half Life: Opposing Force [/h1] 

[b] A Worthy Expansion To A Classic FPS [/b]

[b] Half Life: Opposing Force [/b] does what many expansion packs fail to do - provide meaningful and fun content in addition to the base experience. By taking control of Andrew Shepard, a member of the military group sent in to kill Gordan Freeman, you get to see the game's original story from a different angle. The level design is improved, the arsenal of weaponry is refined and expanded, and there are new enemies to fight along the way, culminating in a successful expansion of the Half-Life formula!

The levels in [b] Half Life: Opposing Force [/b] provide new sections of the Black Mesa research facility to play through. These areas include new tram levels, sewer levels, and even more encounters with the Pit Monster from the original title.  The jumps and landscape are smoothed a bit better, leading to less instances of falling to your death or getting caught on the environment and staying stuck (although it still happened multiple times). While buggy, the levels look interesting, and play just as well as the original titles.

There are also new additions to Shepard's arsenal, such as an LMG, Transporter gun, Electric Shock Rifle, Heavy Pistol, and a grappling hook. This adds new ways to approach combat, as well as get around the environment, something that still occurred in the base game but at a much less frequent rate. Enemies also pack these weapons as well, so the ability to take and deal a lot of damage is enticing.

Lastly, new enemy types are introduced. All seem to be dangerous, ranging from Shock Troopers to Voltigores, to even an encounter with a helicopter like in the base game. These enemies introduce a new level of difficulty to the title, and cause the player to have to approach each section with care and awareness. I did feel that some sections of the game where multiple Voltigores would spawn were a too difficult, but I have to give Gearbox credit for adding something different to the Half-Life experience.

All in all, this was a fun expansion to play through, and I [b] Recommend [/b] it to any fans of the original game or FPS games in general. There was enough new content, enemies, and locations to run through, despite it still being a retelling of the base game from a different perspective a la [b] Half Life: Blue Shift [/b]. Unlike that expansion, [b] Half Life: Opposing Force [/b] serves as a fun change of pace for the original game, which is good enough for myself!

[h2] Final Verdict: 8/10 (Great) [/h2]

If you enjoyed this review, feel free to check out my curator page for my thoughts on a variety of other games!

Opposing Force, surprisingly enough, surpasses the original Half-Life in certain ways. One being combat, I thought the FPS mechanics in this game were more exciting. I think the game I'd compare it most to would be F.E.A.R., which is an absolute master in the ways of horror and first-person shooting. 

Overall this is a solid expansion to Half-Life, and if you enjoyed the original game, then I'm sure you'd enjoy this one.

58592050.review:
Half-Life: Opposing Force is an expansion for the original Half-Life. This time you are Corporal Shepard, a soldier tasked with hunting down Gordon Freeman while fending of aliens at the same time. It soon turns out that in general chaos everyone fights everyone, including new alien species and black ops soldiers. 
There are a few new weapons (alien lightning gun, Desert Eagle) and some new features. You get to lead other soldiers with various specialties: engineer who can cut doors, medic who can heal you. You learn to climb ropes and at one point you can use alien technology of grappling gun. 

Music sets the mood nicely, especially dynamic themes when something serious is going down. 
It's 2019 and I definitely enjoyed playing Half-Life: Opposing Force!

58343131.review:
If you played the original Half-Life, you would really enjoy Opposing Force. An expansion for the already revolutionary Half-Life following a new protagonist, Adrian Shepherd. Opposing Force introduces new gameplay elements such as new weapons, a grappling hook, squad interactions which was later inplemented to Half-Life 2, etc. Story was a focus on the marines' perspective during the events of Half-Life. Also got more hints and story to the mysterious G-man in the last game. Definitely a must play if you enjoyed the original Half Life.

Some annoying issues with the game is the glitches, dated AI, and crashes, but we can all ignore that. 

Thanks to Half-Life Opposing force, it helped kickstarted Gearbox Software that later gave us Borderlands Series but sadly, Borderlands and a few other titles were really excellent games and other titles such as Duke Nukem Forever, Aliens: Colonel Marines, Battleborn were quite crappy.  Finally Valve is taking development to Half-Life: Alyx which hopefully would bring Half-Life series back from the dead, and hopefully we could see a future story with Adrian Shepherd.


Edit 18/05/2020
Valve released Half-Life:Alyx, if Half-Life 3 were to ever be released, Valve stated themselves they want it to revolutionize the video game industry so we all have to be patient.
