58057582.review:
Half-Life: Opposing Force is a stand-alone expansion for the classic hit Half-Life. You play as a US Marine, Adrian Shephard, who was assigned the task of cleaning up a Resonance Cascade at the Black Mesa facility (a Resonance Cascade is basically a massive alien invasion caused by unstable teleportation experiments). Adrian and his squad catch a helicopter ride to the testing facility, but are attacked by alien ships. After crash landing inside Black Mesa, the marine wakes up to a scientist giving him CPR. However, Adrian knows his mission is to eliminate anyone who knows about the alien invasion. The choice is up to you if you spare the lives of naive scientists or murder everything in sight.

(P.S.) This expansion often goes on sale, usually costing around a dollar or less. I recommend that you wait for a sale before purchasing, as it is quite short.

57175484.review:
There will never be games/mods like this, at least in my eyes. A parallel look at what happens in Black Mesa and what characters/groups are thinking.

First off, to begin, they are plenty of new weapons to use in OF that I think are insanely fun. Blue Shift has an interesting story, but less weapons than HL and OF.

Secondly, the story is superior to that of BS. Although this is heavily opinion based to say, I believe the point of view from the military group is better than the point of view of a guard at Black Mesa.

However, for something less opinion based, here's some points I'll make:
-Servers are still active and include all these fun weapons
-Amazing ambient music and action-paced music
-Difficult but not crazily difficult (adds difficulty from HL and removes complexity from certain aspects like the whole Silo section vs. The Pit Worm chapter)
-Almost double the amount of sections than in Blue Shift, but slightly less than Half-Life

All in all, strongly recommend BUT I suggest owning the first Half-Life game before playing as it'll be insanely confusing.

I started with the first Halflife and I liked it. This game is very similar to the first Halflife and the story happens paralel to the story of Halflife but with another character. So here's my rating.

Gameplay: Good (same as Halflife)
Shooting experience: good (same as Halflife, dont expect same details as newer games its a 1999 game)
Story: Good (of course not so good like Halflife but was also interesting).
Graphics: good for its time. 1999 game graphics, similar to PlayStation 1 games.
HUD and user friendliness: Bad. Like Halflife, there is no mission tracking or mini map, so if you save your process and play again next day you may not remember what to do next. So listen carefully to the NPCs, they tell you what to do.

In overall if you have played Halflife and liked it, then you must play this game also. It was first supposed to be an addon but now its like a standalone addon, dont need Halflife to be installed to play it.

Like Halflife it supports Full HD resolution 1920x1080. I played on windows 10 with i5 and GTX 1060. Some minor glitches and bugs but not disturbing. I had 2 or 3 crashes without error closed to the end of the game. It was when walking to a new area, then Halflife needs 2-3 seconds to load the new area and game freezes for a short time. If you walk many times forth and back of that loading spot then game might crash. So try to avoid this.

This game is at least as much fun as the original Half-Life. That is – excellent level design, original game mechanics, and when you think you have seen it all, there is something new – it never gets repetitive (as some modern games do), you are never bored.

What is not so great is sound quality (very low bitrate audio – it sometimes even get irritating) and poor AI of your allies, which can get annoying – but hey, it’s a 20 year old game.

I also had to increase the FOV in the console, which cannot be changed in the game settings, and its default value is too small for modern monitors. On the other hand, I appreciate the support of any resolution and aspect ratio (I play at 3840 × 1600).

Overall, I rate the game very positively. I played it for the first time this year and I regret not knowing about it long ago.

54556957.review:
Arguably vastly superior to the original in all aspects, bar length, Back in the bronze age, this was known as a challenging game. In >current year, I'd not be surprised if the average gamer finds it very difficult. Unlike HL, this game focuses on combat (you're a HECU marine sent in to 'silence' the facility and all associated assets) and, though primitive, things like taking cover behind terrain, baiting enemies with grenades, scoring fat gibs with the handful of satchels the game gives you, and using your advanced AI (for the late 90s) squad members properly is satisfying, and a reward all of its own, not to mention the huge selection of new weapons that augment the arsenal.

The theme of the game, for those who are interested in such things, is 'survival at all costs.'

The game's fairly stingy with supplies, but early into the game, you're given a special weapon that's all-but useless for offensive purposes, but teleports you to hazardous breather locations, as it were, where supplies, healing ponds, and so on, may be found - however, ammunition for this weapon is extremely limited, so you'll at most be using it once per level.

I played this when it came out, almost 20 years ago, and it still holds up today - though you'll want to set a more modern resolution, and tune the uber dark environments to accommodate 20 years of monitor technology and progress. About 8000k to 9300k monitor temperature  should do the trick, then adjust the actual contrast, and you'll be fragging like it's the 90s.

Highly recommended. One of my favorite oldschool shooters. It was then, it is now, and likely forever will be. If you're skimping out on this one, you're doing yourself a great disservice.

I highly recommend this and Blue Shift to anyone who already owns and has beat the first Half-Life

[h1][b] Half-Life: Opposing Force [/b][/h1]
[quote=Half-Life] Ah shit, here we go again [/quote]

[b][u] Introduction [/u][/b]
On the job of finishing the whole Half-Life I stumbled upon the fact there are two expansions on Steam. Opposing Force is one of these. It introduces the greatest character in all of Half-Life... Adrian Shephard. The Opposing Force also adds changes a few things. As you may imagine at the end of the game you have different weapons than you'd have if you played OG Half-Life. It creates new interesting opportunities to make this experience unique and not only a repetition of the same as in one other expansion.
The marks I give in this review are mine and mine alone. I will be granting points, from 1 to 10, according to my choice and I will try to add comments whenever neccessary.

[table]
[tr]
[th]Criterion[/th]
[th]Mark[/th]
[th]Comments[/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[th]Story[/th]
[th]8/10[/th]

[th]Audio[/th]

[/tr]
[tr]
[th]Controls[/th]
[th]9/10[/th]
[th]Would be 10/10 if not for the crouch jump, Ctrl+Space is not intuitive, changing crouching key to key of choice makes it more bearable[/th]
[/tr]
[/table]

[b][u] Important notes [/u][/b]
If you finished this expansion and want more I recommend playing through another official expansion for Half-Life that was not released on PC. It is named [i] Decay [/i]. Thanks to the gracious Half-Life modding community all PC users can experience this expansion in full glory. To download the modification click >>[url=https://www.moddb.com/mods/half-life-decay/downloads/half-life-decay] HERE [/url]<<

[b][u] Conclusion [/u][/b]
Looking back at this experience I think I enjoyed this expansion a little more than the original Half-Life. I have finished it in 6 hours, but I am really bad at these kind of games. You can finish this expansion in half the time I spent on it. It is easily one of the best experiences I had ever pleasure of playing.

54354231.review:
In Opposing Force, you are a faceless U.S. Marine by the name of Adrian Shephard with a job to do. Suddenly, you are put into advanced training for dealing with top secret research facilities because of that pesky G-man and his employers, and are sent to Black Mesa after it all goes downhill.
You never received your orders..so you end up trying to make sense of all of the chaos while your fellow Marines perish as the chaos unfolds.
Scientists and security are reluctant to help, and you do run into sparse Marine specialists to help you along the way to Lambda Complex, where you are trying to prevent a serious alien invasion from destroying the area. 
Eventually you win, and Adrian is put into a place by the G-man to be retained for 'potential future employment'

This expansion wanted to shed light on the Resonance Cascade through the eyes of the Black Mesa 'clean up crew', and see how it was on the other side of the fight. There are new mechanics, such as the ability to control specialized Marines that can open doors and heal you. There is also (awful) rope physics! Multiplayer was introduced in this expansion, but I have never played it so I can't speak for it.
The graphics, sound, AI, voice acting, controls, and general design of the game are exactly the same as the original Half-Life.

Play this if you want to see a side story set during the Resonance Cascade. And don't skip the boot camp! (training room)

6/10 because the difficulty of this one is insane compared to the base game.

54193687.review:
If you liked the OG Half-Life, you'll like this one. Personally, I didn't like the OG Half-Life TOO much, from the BS cheap enemy spawns and the overreliance on bad first person platforming that makes the player save scum whether they want to or not. Is all that still in this expansion campaign? Yes, but lessened, and the campaign is shorter so it doesn't overstay its welcome.

I also found the weapon selection, while only SLIGHTLY varied from the first one, is an improvement. The special ops handgun that replaces the magnum in the original is great, the .50 cal (I think it's an FAL, not sure though) rules, and the alien guns, I thought, were way more useful. 

There's also more of a focus in this game on using survivors that you find and keeping them alive to help you out and use them in contextual situations than the first one, and I think that works well here. 

The only down side was that there were some tech problems getting this one up and running, as it wouldn't open properly and Steam seemed to think that the game was running when it was not. So I had to restart my computer, open the game, close hl.exe in my task manager, have Steam verify the files, THEN open the game again and it would work. Luckily, I was able to beat the game in 3 separate sessions, so I could uninstall this one quick, haha. Yeah, maybe it was just a computer problem locally, but I haven't had that problem with any other game on my Steam library, except for a slightly similar problem with Hitman Blood Money. Strange, be on the lookout for problems with this one. Some troubleshooting may be required.

The plot is also pretty cool, as they did a good job having it overlap with the original game, where the first 2/3rds of this game take place over the second half of the original, but from a separate perspective, humanizing the military a little more where in the OG they were just 100% evil and unsympathetic. You also get to see that Freeman wasn't the ONLY person the G-Man was utilizing to fulfill his ends.

All in all, where the OG Half-Life left a bit of a bitter taste in my mouth over the more aggravating aspects and flaws of the game that really built up near the end half, I didn't have as much of a problem with this one, as they had figured it out a little bit more and were just throwing together a short side campaign, and I thought it worked.

If you just care about the plot of Half-Life and the origins of Freeman, you're better off just playing the first one and then moving on to the second one, but if you just want to see what the gameplay of the original is like but want less frustrations, or if you REALLY liked the OG and want more of it, then try this one. It's less than $1 on sale, and if you bought the original Half-Life in a cheap pack on sale, then you already own this one.

Man, what an experience.

I haven't [b] properly [/b] played a Half-Life in 15 years. That said, I was expecting something else. I've experienced many FPS games in these years, I've seen it all. But the Half-Life expansions have really missed my library, until this recent summer sale when I purchased the Valve Complete Pack.

[h1] The Best Half-Life there is [/h1]

For some, that may be an overstatement, but hear me out. I've now played ALL the half-life games. HL1, HL2, Blue Shift, Opposing Force, Decay (PS2) and even Uplink (the demo to HL1). But Opposing Force did something better than the others, it gave this series a true personality. 

Let me explain:

So the game is played from the perspective on Cpl. Adrian Shepard, a HECU Marine sent to investigate the Black Mesa incident once a phenomenon know as a "resonance cascade" allowed for a sudden alien invasion. The unit that Shepard is sent with is kinda late, as the game begins sometime after the chapter "Surface Tension" in Half-Life. The story connects instantly, as one of the Apache helicopter that accompanies Shepard's squad flies off to intercept Gordon Freeman, who is now outside and "on the loose" trying to fight his way to the Lambda Complex. Shortly after, your helicopter gets shot down and the fight immediately begins to erupt. Marines vs Aliens, all-out-war.

You wake up after an unknown amount of time, sometime before the beginning of "Forget about Freeman". The story becomes no longer after investigating the attack, but getting out of the facility. The situation is out of control, everyone runs for their lives, including the marines.

From here on out, from the order to "get out" and all the way until the ending, you must fight through Black Mesa with you military skills and some other help. This "help" comes in the form of your fellow marine friends, who will assist you in combat. There are a couple of classes that can help you. The Medic (who heals you), the engineer (who opens doors for you) and the heavy weapons guy (a dude with an LMG who kills everything in his path). There are also some generic soldiers like the gas mask guy and the lieutenant, who are both useless in combat, but I'll touch on that later.

The way that this expansion is the definitive Half-Life experience is due to the addition of many more things that weren't present on Half-Life. New aliens (a giant tank-like alien, a creature that shoots some sort of electrical weapon, and a smaller creature with claws that can leap to you and kill you in a couple of hits), new weapons (LMG, Sniper, Deagle, some sort of fish that instakills anything, a barnacle that can be used to attach to walls and climb unreachable aliens, and a launcher that can teleport you or other creatures to Xen), and also cool new bosses like a giant worm-like creature and the final one, which is a colossal amalgamation between all other aliens (i think). All of this is topped by the Black Ops soldiers, your sworn enemies, who are even deadlier than in the original game. There are multiple types of Black Ops, from the regular ninjas to the Black Ops soldiers, who are heavily armored, take longer to kill and can easily flank you and kill you if you're not strategic enough.

The puzzle mechanics of Half-Life have been reduced a bit, there's way less platforming and instead the expansion focuses more on combat rather than just jumping through levels, but the supplement of new enemies and weapons provides for a much more fun experience. All of the action sequences are really well done, you always feel on the edge, running and dodging bullets from the Black Ops, and outsmarting the aliens at every step. You will feel accomplished, overwhelmed, a bit tired, but that's what Black Mesa does to you, I guess.

Many themes are picked up in Opposing Force, and your main objective of investigating the attack (you never got the order to silence the witnesses, so killing scientists is not one of your priorities, neither is Freeman, since the order was to "forget about freeman") suddenly become about escaping the facility, later about disarming the nuke that the Black Ops set up in order to end the facilty once and for all, and at the end, you're supposed to finish off the "nastiest thing yet", the final boss in order to escape Black Mesa and aid in saving the world (although Mr.Freeman did that already, I guess).

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

So did Opposing Force live up to my expectations? Yes, it did. I came back to this franchise years later, and I finished the first game's trilogy with a bang. O.F. was that bang, exactly what the series needed, and the amount of content is incredible. 

Some cons? Sure, the AI of your companions is a bit crap (they will get stuck in doors and not attack enemies) and also some pacing issues at the beginning but overall the game is solid.

[h1] 9.5/10 [/h1]

51397897.review:
Half-life opposing force was an expansion game to the half-life game series, that came to the fans that wanted more from half-life, after the success of the first half life. And like the first half life, this game succeed as well.

This game set in the area of time after Gordon freeman opened the portals to the aliens the enter to earth, and lets you see the story from a different point of view, as for the point of view of the US marines who came to destroy every sign of black mesa’s existence after the big incident.

In the game you play as admiral Shepard, a soldier which is part of the US marine, who came to destroy black mesa after the big incident, but his squad’s helicopter crashed, and he was left alone to try and get out of black mesa, with the goal of killing Gordon freeman in the way, but also to keep himself alive as much as he can.

The story of the new game is great and shows the reasons why the first half life was a great success, featuring great new levels with enemies and bosses to fight, and with new puzzle to think through like the first half life did.
  
Through the story you will encounter some new types of enemies and bosses that weren’t present in the first game, and get to use new sets of weapons, which a lot of them are fun to use. With that, because in this game you play as part of the US marines and not against them, like in the first half life, you get to regroup with soldier teammates that will help you to fight the aliens, and unlike the guards in the first half life, those US marines hold with them heavy and more damaging weapons like the SMG from the first half life, shotguns and even machine guns, while the guards in the first half life used only pistols, and could insist less amount of damage with that. Another new mechanic that wasn’t in the first half life and got added to this game is the ability to climb up ropes. Even know it fresh the mechanic of the game, I found it being more annoying then helpful in most situations, because of how similar it is to an enemy alien that will grab you up to kill you.

While the game was very fun, and keeps itself as quality as the first game in the series, the game still lacks consistency with the main character’s morals and goals. Because in the game I play as admiral Shepard, and his goals is to destroy black mesa, I should not help scientists and guards lives in my journey to escape black mesa, and instead arrest them or kill them instead of helping them so they would help me escape by opening locked doors like in the first half life. Another flaw in the game for me is that throughout the game you get to use more and more experimental and alien weapons, instead of more weapons that used in the US army. While those flaws minor, and doesn’t destroy the experience the first half life was known for, those still effect my thoughts about the story’s main character, Shepard, to see him less as a soldier that came to destroy the place, and more like another Gordon freeman. 

Another problem I faced is with the game’s mouse movement, which unlike the small story flaws I wrote before, this mouse movement problem is a big issue. the problem is that sometimes the crosshairs gets bugged when you move it, making it horrible to aim, and would make you sometimes get stuck for a long period of time on the same part of the level just because the crosshair gets bugged all the time and you can’t aim at the enemy because of it. This problem is even harder in multiplayer, in which the enemy players always jumping and moving, and those buggy crosshair movements are adding to the difficulty of aiming at them. 
Other than that, the game is a great game, and can live as a good expansion to the legacy of the first half life and of the half-life series as a whole, with great levels as the original gives, new complex puzzle levels to solve, great new weapons to experience with, and a masterpiece of a story.

Game pros and cons:
Pros:
-	Great level design.
-	A big diverse amount of fun weapons to use.
-	New and old enemies which are hard and worthwhile.
-	Great story.
-	Very good AI, to the enemies and to the allies.
-	Complex new and old mechanics.
-	New bosses to counter.

Cons:
-	Inconsistent character morals and motives.
-	 Some weapons don’t feet the character role in the game, and remind Gordon freeman more than the main character.
-	Not the freshest graphics (as a game that was made between 1999-2001)
-	Buggy mouse and crosshair control.
-	Short story (can be finished in about a day or so)
-	The multiplayer lacks even more from the buggy mouse and crosshair control.

Game’s settings:
-	First person shooter.
-	Science fiction.
-	Story focused game.
-	Cost 10$ (9.99$).
-	Violent game (contains blood).
-	Half horror half adventure type game.
-	Contains Puzzle levels.
-	Story length is about 9 hours.
-	Contains multiplayer.

*I give this game 7.9/10

PROS: The game has all the polish and finesse of the original Half-Life.  If you enjoy the combat that came with it, this is a much better title, with fewer puzzles, less platforming, but more gun play.  The soundtrack still kicks in at some solid moments, providing tension to amp up the moment.

CONS: If you didn't like the combat in Half-Life, then this is not going to sell you on it.  It's mostly combat, and the problem comes about with a lot of small hallways.  This gives little room to dodge incoming fire.

FINAL: This is a nice little supplement to the original Half-Life story, weighed down only by it's questionable canon nature due to no consequence of the finale.  A fun game for old school FPS fans, but completely unneeded for the broader Half-Life story.

51117819.review:
Half-Life: Opposing Force is basically more of the Half-Life, with a bit of a twist. This time you aren't playing as a scientist trying to escape the facility, you're playing as one of the soldiers sent in to handle the situation. It's Half-Life with some new bits and pieces, new maps, and a new story, so I'll just talk about the new additions and changes. Like the original game, the story serves as an excuse for the gameplay. You play as Corporal Adrian Shephard, generic mute action protagonist military man, on his journey to survive and save as many people as possible. The story is a nice spin on the original plot, where you get put in the shoes of a generic enemy soldier from the first game. It gives some insight on why the soldiers start killing innocents and have an obsession with killing Freeman, but more could be done with it. Overall the story is good and provides a fun change of pace from the first game. The gameplay is still as fun as it was in the first game, with some new features such as the tentacle grapple and rope climbing. While they are fun to use, the new features often get put to the sidelines for so long that you forget they exist, so when the odd section comes along expecting you to use them, you might get confused and lost before figuring out what you're supposed to do. One feature that sounds fun on paper, but gets more tedious in practice is the inclusion of squad gameplay. Shephard can command a different soldiers to follow him around and help in combat, with different classes offering different advantages. It's fun at first, but later on it gets annoying as the ally soldier AI tends to get in the way, get into firefights with each other, act dumb and get killed, or act dumb and get you killed. It's a neat concept that I overall enjoy, but it's heavily hindered by poor AI. The new guns added to the game are fun, and I found myself enjoying coming up with tactics for when and how to use each one. Like the first game, ammo is scarce enough to enforce strategy, but lets you enjoy using all the different weapons without feeling too limited. The new levels are all great additions. There are firefights with enemy black ops soldiers that feel tense, firefights with aliens that provide different experiences based on alien types, chaotic war zones that are a gigantic cluster of violence and death, and puzzle sections that add a nice break in the gameplay. There's even some horror elements in some of the levels, with darkness being used to create a tense atmosphere where you never really feel safe. I actually like the level design in Opposing Force more than the original Half-Life levels, which is high praise considering I loved the Half-Life stages. The only level that's really a downer for me is the final boss battle, which feels very anti-climactic, especially when compared to the original Half-Life's final boss. The new enemies are also cool and fun to play against, with each of them adding a challenge to overcome that never feels unfair.

Here's a breakdown of the game.

Pros:
-Same great Half-Life gameplay
-Story offers a neat perspective
-Well made levels
-New weapons are fun to use
-The new gameplay mechanics are mostly fun
-New enemies offer new challenges

Cons:
-AI makes squad gameplay annoying
-New gameplay additions aren't used enough
-Anti-climactic final boss

Half-Life: Opposing Force is a great game, and if you like the original Half-Life, it's definitely worth picking up. While not every new feature and level is perfect, they offer enough variety where you'll be sure to find something enjoyable out of them. I fully recommend you give it a go if you like the Half-Life formula, or if you're just interested in a different take on the events of the first game.

51002633.review:
I have some pretty mixed feelings about this to be honest. The new weapons are really cool, and I really like the LMG. But, you don't really get any ammo at all for the new guns, so it makes using them feel like you're giving something up; which could have easily been solved by just introducing enemies that use the new guns.

While the majority of the single player campaign is great, the last few chapters feel pretty unbalanced, especially because of the Race X (see https://half-life.fandom.com/wiki/Race_X) bullet sponges that appear. They make a large part of the combat from after you first meet them just tedious. You can especially see it in the chapter that you kill the gargantua in.

But, there is one thing---one legend---that makes this expansion an absolute must play: Otis. Otis is a sexy god that has infinite power over vending machines and my penis. He can do no wrong, and is actually the one responsible for defeating the combine in episode 3. Every time I see Otis I just feel an explosion in my pants---and I don't keep grenades in my pocket.

49404564.review:
So I finished the first Half Life last summer and found it to be a pretty great game albeit with a few fairly big flaws. It's expansion, Opposing Force, unfortunately has these exact same flaws so it's disappointing nothing was improved upon here. The first problem is that there are several sections where the difficult spikes to an insane degree, placing you in rooms with no escape surrounded by way too many enemies, many of whom are complete bullet sponges that only serve to eat up your ammo. There were several points in the game that were just exhausting to play through, as I was constantly save scumming and searching every nook and cranny desperately for just one measly med pack. Another problem in this game, like the previous entry, is that the level design can get quite confusing at times and forces you to backtrack fairly often. This is made even worse in this game by the fact that in certain sections you have a squad that you must direct through the hallways and corridors in order to advance to the next section. I'll just say that the path-finding AI was still very primitive for it's time and these sections probably should have been skipped all together. By far the worst flaw however is the fucking platforming. My god has the platforming not aged well with these games at all. There is no weight to your character and you feel like you're floating on a pocket of air or sliding on ice pretty much the whole game. Sounds like the perfect physics system to include platforming doesn't it? I was almost driven to tears in the original Half Life due to platforming bullshit rearing its ugly head in the final boss fight. Thankfully, the final boss in this game is not nearly as hair pulling, but there are still several ugly sections that require death after death until you nail the jump just right.

Now to what I enjoyed. The combat in this game is still top notch and the tension is incredibly high. There are no slow moments in this game and no chance to breathe, it's an action packed thrill ride from start to finish. I'm not sure if this is one of the first games to do the multiple perspectives on an event thing (I know Resident Evil 2 did this a year earlier), but it does it well and you really feel like complete hell and chaos is happening around you through radio broadcasts and several in game cut-scenes. The game itself starts about one hour or so before the end of the original Half Life and greatly expands on the lore of the world, adding many new weapons and enemies to keep the experience fresh. Only real complaint about the story I can come up with is that I thought the build up to the final boss was quite weak. In the original you go through a ton of shit to finally get to the creature who opened the portal in the first place and it's built up as this huge powerful entity that isn't to be fucked with. In this game you just suddenly find yourself in an ammo supply room and are told "something big is coming". It felt pretty underwhelming.

Overall it was a pretty positive experience with the same flaws as the original game. I definitely enjoyed my time with it and look forward to the next expansion, Blue Shift, to finish out the trilogy

49049951.review:
Easily the most underrated game in the Half life series. You play as Corporal (not Commander) Adrian Shepherd, one of the marines sent to eliminate Gordon Freeman and clean up the mess from the Black Mesa Resonance Cascade...only to find out there's much more to this story than just an accidental alien invasion. 
Here's teh Good/Bad Summary:

Good
- New weapons and monsters, all of which are awesome and change the gameplay in interesting ways.
- Superb (and terrifying) level design which takes full advantage of all these additions (and often in very creative ways).
- Different soldier variants actually give your  teammates some purpose other than just dudes that cover you (Medics heal you, Engineers cut through sealed doors, etc.)
- New creepy soundtrack adds to the atmosphere well.
- A couple neat deja-vu moments.
- 7-hour Expansion Pack (Remember when those were a thing?)
- The downright hilarious (and entirely optional) tutorial alone is worth picking this up...trust me!
- Didn't see that ending coming!

Bad
- Night Vision can get obstructive and has lousy range compared to the original flashlight.
- The irritating as hell final level.
- Final Boss is a bit of a pushover.

9.5 Shock Troopers/10 Just buy it!

Product received for free because this game - along with Doom, Starcraft, Diablo 2, Quake, Unreal Tournament 1999, and the original Half-Life of course - was my childhood; And they haven't aged a day since!

49003965.review:
One of my Favorite Expansion packs in general. Instead of playing as Gordon Freeman in Half-Life 1 or Barney Calhoun the Security Guard in Blue Shift... 

You play as an Hazardous Environment Combat Unit Soldier known as Adrian Shepard, one of the enemies in Half-life 1 and Blue Shifts who you know get play as...

Opposing force replaces some of the weapons in Half-Life 1 ( You can still find & use them in Multiplayer mode or by using Cheats. )

The Crowbar is replaced by a Pipe Wrench. 
Which is slower, but is much more powerful and has a charge up attack which can deal even more damage.

And the Revolver is replaced by an Desert Eagle. With an Laser Sight and fires slightly more faster than the Revolver .

And the Sniper Rifle replaces the Crossbow and the Hive hand is replaced by the more useful Shock roach along with Tau Cannon and Gluon gun not appearing but replaced by the more deadly and powerful Displacer Cannon, which is this Expansion's BFG...

You also fight new enemies in this Expansion with Black Ops Assassins replacing the HECU Grunts from HL1 & Blue Shift since you're playing as an HECU Grunt. And the X-Race who are the toughest enemies who you will fight, and a new Headcrab Zombie known as the Gonomes who are tougher than regular zombies who can throw their guts at you as their ranged attack.

Along with new Allies such as some HECU Buddies such as the Engineer who can open welded doors and the Combat Medic who is a Portable Healing Station along with some HECU Grunts wielding an M249 SAW ( One of the new weapons that you can use. ) and a new Black Mesa Fat Security guard known as Otis who uses an Desert Eagle instead of an 9mm Pistol.

Long Story short, you're playing as an HECU Grunt to clean up the Black Mesa incident, and things don't go to well and you're forced to fight the Black Ops and you have encountered a new Alien Race known as Race-X but you encounter your HECU Buddies and knowing that they are left behind and forced to fight the Black Ops and the Xen Aliens along with the after mentioned Race-X, you will find a lot of action in this Expansion Pack with some intense action in some chapters. But i'm leaving the important bits out of here.

I have one complain though. Compared to the CD Retail version, the Menu Screen is less cooler compared to the Animated Title with Soldiers marching in the Opposing Force Title with Helicopters flying and Tanks moving to the Right.
What we got is Adrian Shepard and Gordon Freeman holding Flags for the CTF Mode which i don't play ( Since play Half-Life mostly for it's Single Player Campaigns. )

However that doesn't hurt what this Expansion Pack brings into Half-Life 1 for it's content. You got New Weapons to play with, New Enemies and Aliens to fight along with new Allies that will help you and a enjoyable single-player Campaign...

Also this Expansion pack introduces Rope Climbing which wasn't used in future Half-Life games or any other games made by Valve or Gearbox software... And also a Barnacle that you can use as an Weapon which is Opposing force's grappling hook.

Opposing Force is a really good Half-Life expansion. If you liked the original game, then you'll probably enjoy this as well.

When I started the Training level, I was a bit worried about what the gameplay might consist of due to it teaching you to lead various troops and climbing/swinging on really janky ropes, but thankfully they're used so sparingly that it all works well.

The campaign takes approximately 6-7 hours to complete. There's also multiplayer, but I don't know how active it is in general. I did see a couple servers with a handful of players when I checked.

The story is a neat spin on the original Half-Life's storyline, having you play on the military side to [i]hunt down the Freeman[/i].

The gameplay is similar to Half-Life, but Opposing Force brings in several new weapons into the mix.

Definitely give it a shot if you liked Half-Life.

48712951.review:
This review continues my adventures revisiting the HL series 20 years later. As I have pointed out in my previous reviews for HL & HL Blue Shift the graphics may not be up to today’s standards, the game play and AI are not overly sophisticated, but this is a trip down memory lane with one of the most important vintage FPS game changers.

You are either a HL fan or not, but there is no disputing the fact that there is still a huge HL community, creating some incredible mods, maps and keeping this game alive.
 
Anyway, back to the review. Having played as Gordon & Barney - Half-Life: Opposing Force lets you see Half-life´s story through the eyes of Marine Corporal Adrian Shephard. Who, after surviving a helicopter crash, has to make his way through Black Mesa and survive (similar theme here). However, what I did like were some subtle changes in the game play and weapons.

[*] The crowbar has been replaced with a wrench, which actually appeared to handle heavier with I felt added some realistic physics to the weapon.
[*] The desert Eagle has a laser target; to be honest I do prefer to play with pistols rather than high powered weapons all the time. Having said that, the M249 SAW is just a weapon of mass carnage and is brutally fun.
[*] There are a couple of new Alien Tech weapons such as the awesome Shock Roach, Spore Gun. One fun addition is the ability to collect Snarks (little deadly hyperactive bugs which you can throw and they run around attacking anything they can find, including you at times).

[/list]Some other nice touches are the way you can get some actual help form the AI characters, as with HL and Blue Shift there is some interaction with Scientists who usually open doors or heal you and Security guards who help with shooting the aliens, HL OP takes AI co op a little further where you can join up with other Marines and actually do some real damage. In addition, finding a medic to help heal the engineer to flame cut a sealed door was definitely a nice addition for some limited squad based gameplay.

Overall, Opposing Forces was a great way to end the debut of Half Life and each expansion pack added its own take on the Black Mesa Facility storyline. Opposing forces for me, and remember this is only my opinion, is a far better gameplay experience than the base HL release, however that is definitely down to the popularity of HL and the development of the game 2 years down the line.

A definite must own for true FPS gamers.

Also worth checking out the walkthrough
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=163587409

48406492.review:
A Half-Life game where you play as a HECU soldier? It sure sounds like a good idea, but this game definitely isn't it.

It's a pathetic cop out. Your character (which of course speaks and you can't hear it, screw the very things that make Half-Life good) ends up surviving a helicopter crash (I sure have never heard of that before) and ends up running through plenty of poorly designed maps (of much lower quality than original Half-Life) with a ridiculous amount of invisible walls. By the time you get a gun in your hand, HECU is already retreating, and the entire plot is just artificially extended by G-Man closing your door right in front of you. His character doesn't even fit with how he normally acts, he participates in action too much.

Performance is atrocious at times, thanks to the abuse of dynamic lights. Enabling the night vision goggles causes the framerate to drop into star fox levels, much worse than original Half-Life (Valve is to blame here with their broken port of the goldsrc engine and patches removing functionality, but this game is so bad that it crashed on me, something no other goldsrc game ever did). Pretty much every elevator with mesh floor is broken, at times so bad that I can even get stuck using it normally. The entry vent to pit worm's nest has a known bug where it randomly causes you to get stuck on your way in, and nobody bothered to fix that, the only advice you can find is to load an earlier save and try again. The final boss fight has a game-breaking bug as well. In many cases, after defeating it nothing happens (in my case, nothing happened in all 3 times I've defeated it). That bug has been known for years, hasn't been fixed, and the ad-hoc solution is to manually load the final map from the console.

Gearbox HAD to shove their deviantArt-tier alien Race X (which Freeman and Calhoun haven't seen) into the game. They look like an attempt to model 3-year-old child's drawings and are probably as original as ones such a child would come up with. Ammo sponges is the best way I can describe them. There are WAY too many fights where you just get thrown against a way too large group of enemies, and it gets repetitive really quick. Do you hate black ops from Half-Life? Enjoy countless fights with them, ones where you end up with more enemies spawning should you decide to pick up some ammo or a medkit from an earlier area. The only enjoyable thing is the wrench, which while slow (not a problem since there are more melee weapons in this game, plenty of weapons feel like duplicates of each other) can gib characters instantly from their full health. The sad part is that you don't fight against Black Mesa personel, something I hoped for in this game. I expected to have moments where I have to fight against guards and slay scientists, all of them end up being friendly to you for no good reason. AI of soldiers you encounter is somehow worse than original Half-Life, at least they seem to be able to take more damage and have better weapons, so using them to conserve ammo works better (and there's way too little of it in the game, expect to run around enemies to have something for cases where you actually need to fight).

The idea with a detached barnacle used as a weapon is good, but of course it had to get executed poorly.

If you happen to own this game, don't even bother downloading it as it is a waste of time.

TL;DR: the plot is a cop out, fights are repetitive and annoying, Gearbox took the source material too loosely and lost the grasp on what made Half-Life good, and replaced it with bugs.

As the first expansion pack for Half-Life 1, you trade in your HEV suit and step into the boots of Cpl. Adrian Shephard as you experience Black Mesa from a different perspective, being that of the military.

Being an expansion pack, Opposing Force introduces new weapons and enemies that you'll encounter along the way as you work towards your goal of eliminating Gordon Freeman.

A definite must have for fans of Half-Life 1.

48197896.review:
After playing the original Half Life, I was quite curious to see what this expansion was about and oddly enough I was a little on the fence at first when I started playing it, but as I progressed I started to appreciate it more and I really did enjoy this title. 

Opposing Force essentially is the HECU side of the Black Mesa incident, you play as Corporal Adrian Shephard and are tasked with assisting in stopping the aliens and hunting Gordon Freeman. The HECU side of the Black Mesa incident isn't too touched upon and thus it's really interesting to see what they went through and the little things happening behind the scenes. Opposing Force adds new weapons and enemy types. The weapons are quite fun and very satisfying to use and I like how the style is different from the original Half Life. The new enemies are more difficult than the original Half Life, they can soak up more damage and inflict more damage and get really annoying though their designs are quite cool. You also get new allies, HECU Marines, Engineers, and Medics can help you fight off enemies and it's kinda fun fighting like a squad with them. There are also climbing ropes that weren't seen in the original Half Life that you can swing from which are unique. This game is short though and you'll get about 2-4 hours of gameplay give or take (This is expected from an expansion though).

As I said before the new enemies in the game are quite annoying and challenging to face (at least for me). Especially the shock troopers which will pretty much constantly take down your health and can take alot of hits back if they aren't dealt with quickly.

This game is a nice sidestory and another perspective to the Black Mesa incident. If you like Half Life and want more of it, I recommend this game, though you aren't missing out on anything if you don't play it.

47340787.review:
These days when you think of Gearbox Software you probably think of either the unbelievably popular [i]Borderlands[/i] series or the believably unpopular [i]Aliens: Colonial Marines[/i]. In general you probably don’t think of anything good, but did you know that Gearbox’s first projects were [i]Half-Life[/i] expansions [i]Opposing Force[/i] and [i]Blue Shift[/i]? Probably not, since neither of them were very noteworthy or good. [i]Opposing Force[/i] was pretty clearly the one that all the time and money was pumped into. We play as Corporal Adrian Shephard of the HECU, an antagonistic U.S. military unit from the base game sent into Black Mesa to kill all the witnesses to the resonance cascade and subsequent alien invasion. [i]Opposing Force[/i] conveniently dodges making Shephard an actual baddie by having his helicopter crash on the way to Black Mesa. As such we wake up after being brought to safety by a group of scientists and have to fight our way out of the facility. Along the way we fight assorted enemies including the aliens from the base game, a couple of aliens not from the base game, and the black ops unit from the first game. We’re given an assortment of different weapons including a sniper rifle, machine gun, and a handheld version of the barnacle enemy complete with gross, long tongue!

You may even use some of these new weapons, but the easiest way to win is to stick with the basic pistol, which features a laser sight and is so absurdly powerful that there’s really no reason to use any of the cool alien guns you’re stocked up with over the game’s runtime. The most fun I had with [i]Opposing Force[/i] was swinging on the janky barnacle tongue, which was great when it didn’t bug out and kill me. The game has some very large areas compared to the base game, but unless you’re playing this in 1999 there’s nothing especially impressive going on here. [i]Opposing Force[/i]’s real issue is that it has new weapons and levels, but no new ideas. Nothing as original or exciting as what was on display in the original [i]Half-Life[/i] is present here, and taking place concurrently with the base game just means it’s treading water narratively as well as mechanically. The point is I went in with tempered expectations (I knew that this came out almost 20 years ago and that Gearbox made it), but was still disappointed. The temptation to play this expansions out of love for [i]Half-Life[/i] is a common one, and I cannot recommend strongly enough that you disregard it and just go outside instead.

44776476.review:
Not short and sweet like Blue Shift, and not nearly as engaging as Half-Life itself, Opposing Force is an interesting side story which ultimately is dragged incredibly far, and wears its welcome thin.

In this one, you play 'Adrian Shepard' and you're just a marine. The game goes on forever, it just keeps going, on and on and on and on, it picks up some time late in Half-Life. There's actually, shockingly no clear plot or anything, since maybe a chapter or two in you get to the point where you're going to leave Black Mesa with the rest of the soldiers, and G-Man steps in to stop you... for some reason, and then the rest of the game is just nonsense. You just... go through Black Mesa, fightin' and killin' everything in your way.

The only things not hostile to you this time are Black Mesa personnel and fellow soldiers, but there's a new faction of 'black ops' troops who are out to get you... for some reason, so you have to fight those guys. For the most part, your enemies are pretty much just vortigaunts, houndeyes and headcrabs for the first half of the game, then after about that point you're just fighting these weird lookin things which run up and claw you, and then for the last third or so it's almost exclusively these giant things that spit purple lightning balls at you, and these ground troops which shoot blue laser balls.

It's actually horrible, everything does huge amounts of damage to you and there's not much you can do to stop it. I never felt so consistently outgunned in any of the other games, and it might have something to do with the fact that after about the halfway mark, I think Gearbox just completely forgot about giving you anything to do with HP or armor. You're supposed to be able to charge up your combat armor with these military grade chargers as well as the HEV suit chargers, and during training you even see a third party one, but honestly I think I only saw one or maybe two military chargers during the whole game.

Additionally, health is a huge problem. After that halfway mark or so, they just stop placing the medkits on walls, so you only have rarely, a big bunch of crates in a room that have maybe 3-4 health kits as items which restore about 15 hp each, so gaining 45 to 60 health at once. This is nice, but I really felt up against it for that entire third or half of the game, if you ever make a mistake and drop to like 10 or 20 hp, that's it, that's pretty much all you get for what feels like another chapter or so.

There's this one really annoying bit where there's this tunnel system with a whole ton of these spider lookin things that shoot purple lightning, and they take a LOT of hits to kill, and I mean a LOT, like multiple shots with a rocket launcher. I found that the BFG or whatever it is does about 1-shot them as long as you hit them with it, but you only get five shots anyway.

I think it says a lot that I played this game for not even 5 hours, and it felt like 10.

The first third of the game or so feels pretty good, it's fun enough, and playing as Shepard is novel enough to keep you interested, but from then on, perhaps after G-Man stops you boarding the helicopter out, that's when the game just sort of takes a dive. I don't know why, it just stops being fun. Maybe it's because they never really give you anything else to do, and the game culminates in an absolutely pathetic excuse for a boss fight. It doesn't even work properly on Linux, what I found is that once you kill the boss, its model sort of bugs out and it instantly disappears, and it doesn't let you finish the game unless you manually change level to it via the console.

There's some other issues too, like the game not giving you weapons early enough. For example, the Barnacle. You get an actual Barnacle as a 'gun' in this game. You just kind of use it to grapple enemies, you can grab headcrabs and they are tugged right into the maw of the Barnacle, chomp, it's crunched into a giblets. But, anything larger than that, and you get pulled towards it like a grappling hook. Now, everyone knows grappling hooks are super awesome, why didn't they give it to us earlier? You get it only a couple chapters before the end of the game!

Like Counter-Strike: Condition Zero Deleted Scenes, there's a bunch of stuff in the tutorial which doesn't really feel like it's made enough of a big deal of in the game itself. An example is the ropes, in Opposing Force you can climb ropes which act kind of like actual physics objects, it's very impressive, the only issue is the game doesn't really do much with them. I'm not sure if it was a technical limitation or not, but either way, they're very few and far between and the only few times you get to use them are usually just... climbing up a small distance you could have just had a ladder for.

A better use could have been something like... having you use an elevator, it stops, so you need to grab onto the electrical cable and climb down instead while it plummets down below and explodes. That'd be cool! People like seeing stuff blow up. Instead, they're almost all 'just kind of there'.

I should talk a little more about the final boss. It's just a big squid, it can't move, and to kill it you just shoot it in each eye with a pair of laser guns you have to press E to use, and then you shoot it in it's... portal mouth thing until it dies. It's boring, not challenging, and while the Nihilanth in Half-Life is constantly speaking to you, whispering stuff in your ear like as soon as you get to Xen, this thing just kind of shows up! A guard says "hey there's a bad thing coming through a portal and you gotta kill it" and you do that and that's the end of the game. It just ends, G-Man shows up to tell you you're going to be put away now and then it ends. It's very disappointingy.

It's a shame that we never really got a sequel or anything, I'd actually love to see that today, with a stronger emphasis on the differences between the scientist, Dr. Freeman and the veteran soldier, Corporal Adrian Shepard, but... Gearbox is a huge company now, and they probably wouldn't even care about doing it. Valve don't really make games anymore, and everyone's kind of forgotten about Half-Life.

I can't say I disliked Opposing Force, some parts of it are really great. The soldiers are ALL just hamming it up, it's great, you get an intro that's reminiscent of Predator, there's one part with a trash compactor which is like 1:1 with the scene from Star Wars, and the few occasions you get to lead around some of your fellow soldiers, it's fun, it's good, it's just a shame it can't remain like that throughout the whole thing. I'd give it like a thumbs sideways, but since I have to pick one, my affection for the game outweighs my disdain.

44081419.review:
One of the best expansions for a 90s game and for a relatively new developer at the time, I'd say it's well worth playing and probably even better than the base game lol. It has similar problems to Blue Shift and the base game on GldSrc, but that's mostly due to the engine itself rather than the game's fault. I still did had to cheat in some places because I didn't feel like dying and reloading a save file a million times or they seemed to have ledges imposible to reach. Besides those few flaws, Opposing Force is an excellent add-on focusing less on confusing puzzles and frustrating navigation and moreso on the combat and sometimes controlling your...questionable squad.

Yeah the friendly AI in Opposing Force is shit for a 90s game and even so compared to Half Life and Blue Shift. A few times you have to protect friendly AI which enemies can easily kill so watch out! This takes 5-6 hours to beat, almost as long as the base game, the action and immersion was pretty good with slightly better plot and progression. Enemies aren't overpowered anymore and you have new weapons that make the fighting less annoying than the base game...except for those damn Black Ops which are even more buffed in Opposing Force with 2 types. G-Man seems to help you a soldier named Corporal Shepard at times yet will hinder your progress to extend the plot I guess.

I'm not sure if Opposing Force or Blue Shift was included free for Half Life 1 owners, but even if it's now now that is a plus and is very cheap especially on sale so definitley buy this. Unlike Blue Shift and Source, there's also multiplayer albeit with empty and dead servers and playing from a different perspective lets you explore totally new areas that aren't super dark and generic like Blue Shift and spices things up as a soldier. The training tutorial isn't a complete knock-off like Blue Shift's and it's very funny and innovative. I think since the enemies aren't as ridiculous as the other two titles I could probably enjoy this add-on even on normal difficulty; I've beaten this twice and hope to beat it again soon.

43958720.review: Half Life 1 was great. This game, while being about half as long from start to end, is just as good as the HL 1. Maybe even better in some circumstances. It offers several new weapons not found in Half Life, at the expense of a few from HL1 not appearing at all. In addition, not only does Opposing Force have new weapons and level design, it has has entirly new enemy types, mostly for the aliens which you spend most of the game fighting, unlike HL1 where you alternated between military and aliens for most of the game. One of the other benefits is that it doesn't have any real BAD levels. While HL1 had excellent level design, with good mix of shooting,  platforming, and puzzle solving, it also had several moments or levels that fustrated me greatly. From my playthrough of this, I can only really recall a couple of moments that bothered me personally (like the area where if you hit certain explosives you instantly die, just like in HL1 or the final area with the high and strong enemy count). Though it was less the levels themselves and more the enemies you fight. Compared to HL1, Opposing Force throws you against stronger enemies a lot more often, and while it's not terrible, I found it easier to ignore some battles rather than fight my way through. Especially in the final area where they have several rooms that just throw enemies at you with reckless abandon. This does work well for people who wanted a tougher game, but I feel like Half-Life 1 was at a good level of challenge, minus some cheap bullshit it pulled. So I'm not sure if I like the higher base difficulty overall. Another issue is that like Blue Shift, the story is pretty much throwaway. Though, I do appreciate that we see a different view of the situation, even if I think they could have done more with it. (These guys are supposed to go after Freeman, making them like the bad guys killing everything. But then they just turn out to be victims too, which I feel was kind of a cop out) Overall, while there are a few nags I have with the game, it's far outwieghed by the positives of being more Half-Life 1, and the new things it brought to the table. That doesn't even include multiplayer. Yeah, this game had multiplayer. Really odd, but still a nice addition regardless. If you have a spare $5 (or less if you wait for the Valve bundle pack sale) and want more Half-Life, this is an easy yes. You owe it to yourself to play it if you like Half-Life, but haven't touched this game at all.

The gameplay is not very different from that of the original, though there are new weapons and enemies to encounter. You can also work together with other black-ops soldiers, though their AI isn't that good. With an interesting premise and new content, I would recommend "Opposing Force" for anyone who enjoyed playing "Half Life", for it takes a look at the events of that game, and further develops its story.

43261585.review:
For one reason or another I never actually sat down to play this game.  Much like the original HL, Blue Shift and this, I simply never got around to it.  I guess I was too busy playing all the great mods that came out because of HL.  Regardless this is a pretty good game.  A dated game mind you, but still pretty good.  If you enjoyed the original game you should enjoy this as well.  Decent length for an add on, which was about twice as long as Blue Shift, but that still pales in comparison to the original game.  Those not wanting to have to sit through all of HL again, may enjoy a quicker romp through Black Mesa and on the way see side stories that add to the HL universe.

This time around, instead of being Dr. Freeman or the security guard Barney (Original or Blue Shift), you are US Marine Cpl. Shephard in route to Black Mesa.  Your transport is shot down before the standing orders are given to everyone however...  So you are basically left to your own devices in trying to escape the facility.  You meet up with fellow squad mates from time to time, which you can use to advance, security guards and even jittery scientists.  You also have new weapons at your disposal and a slew of new enemies to compliment the old ones, some brain teasers that will have you scratching your head for a solution and you will of course see new areas of Black Mesa.

However the game is not without it's flaws.  Again by now the graphics are outdated.  There is just no way around it.  If you are spoiled on the latest or even decade old graphics, this may not be your bag.  Also they claim you can control your team and give orders.  Sadly this was no different than when you could control the scientists from the original game.  You just use the USE key, they follow and use a blow torch to cut through a door.  That is it.  Maybe you can ask a medic to heal you, but there are so many health packs laying around you really didn't need him.  I was expecting strategy and team work with my fellow soldiers, but there was none of that.  And they die too quickly in a fire fight anyway, even with a medic present.  In fact I am not even sure the medic can heal himself or others if not scripted in the story.  If they could of done better with that expect, I would of praised it much higher.

Also coming from a military background I was a little annoyed at certain weapons having characteristics that they should not have, as well as the night vision goggles that was designed to act as the flashlight in the other games, but it is a game so what ever.  ^_^  Due to the nature of the game being an add on and so dated, I would get it on sale for a dollar.  Nothing to complain about at that price.  And it is that price now as of this writing.  Either that or wait for another Summer or Winter Sale.

43212475.review:
Everyone says this one is the bee's tits but I don't see it.

Half-Life's level design is meticulous, at least for the first half. This one just feels lazy, the obvious solution sometimes isn't even the solution at all. I had a situation where I met a dead end with a vent I couldn't reach and a window leading to a fall that would easily kill me, there wasn't anything I could move or climb to get to the vent so after a few minutes I smashed the window out of frustration and jumped out to- what I thought would be my death only to find a small ledge beneath me that was impossible to see before. A few rooms down I come across a similar problem and bam. Indestructible window. What you're supposed to do is shove your hand up a barnacle's arse and swing across a chasm spiderman style. That is not a joke.

Health/ammo supplies are so low I thought the game was kidding. The new enemies are crack shots and don't feel like the running breathing shooting living AI that you'd find in Half-Life. And they are practically stuffed into levels at an absurd amount to the point that progressing is a brutal slog rife with save-scumming, a constant war of attrition where every hit you take feels like an instant failure, not even in an intense way. Just frustrating.

Story starts off ok, seeing the story from the perspective of the HECU was a logical next step for HL. The first few minutes capture the chaos of the original game pretty well, the Black Mesa scientists attempting to save the protagonist and his team not even knowing they were sent there to kill just about everything in Black Mesa was pretty cool. The story stops there though, you spend the rest of the game just running along until the G-man lets you know when you won it.

It feels weird to say there were too many weapons in a thing, but there are. 16 weapons. In the last leg of the game you must get a good three of them and not a whole lot of time to figure out what they do. By the end of it I spent more time fighting the weapon select than I did any actual aliens, and who needs two melee weapons?

Friendly AI is just as bad as it's always been, don't really want to follow you very much, get stuck a lot and killed more. The fact that they're a gimmick this time though made their flaws a lot more noticeable. I stopped bothering with them really quickly.

The final boss is laughably bad, I thought it was just blocking the door to the final boss until halfway through the fight. You just run around the same room over and over and shoot mounted guns at a thing until it dies. 

Unless you want the bragging rights of beating every Half-Life game (which I did) I wouldn't really bother.

42690823.review: Half-Life: Opposing Force is a story expansion to the original Half-Life, and follows HECU Marine Adrian Sheppard through the events of Black Mesa. This is definitely the better and longer expansion of the two, as Opposing Force adds many new weapons, enemies, and concludes with a new boss fight. The gunplay and "puzzles" hold up to the original game, and Opposing Force also features a squad-like system, where you can lead other HECU Marines through Black Mesa. The ally AI is pretty braindead, but at least you're not alone the entire time. The roughly 4 hour campaign is worth playing through at least once, and this game also features multiplayer deathmatch servers, if that's what you're into.

42688271.review: This expansion pack is fantastic as it contains everything which makes the original game so great such as the terrific level design and the brilliant puzzles, the constant suspense in the way of coming face-to-face with a creature by walking around a corner or a creature spawning next to you or behind you, the linearity which still leaves you with lots of freedom, the great AI of the Black Ops, and the little touches of seeing civilians occasionally die around you as you progress through the levels. Since I already elaborated on these points in my review of Half-Life, however, I don't want to repeat myself, so I'll like to elaborate on a couple other things I liked about this game. When I fought against the marines in the original game, it seemed like they were the villains, but the elaboration of the Black Ops in this game (they were introduced in the main game, but we didn't know much of anything about who they were as we didn't have access to the Marines' equipment) made it seem like they were the true villains. It was an interesting shift which made me question my reaction to the main game. I also liked the extra insight on the G-Man. While most of the details on his character are ambiguous (as they were in the main game), we learn a couple other details about his character (more specifically, actions he takes at the end of the game) which further hint at the bigger picture suggested in the first game. I did notice a couple bugs in this game though. For instance, it was sometimes difficult to get the Marines to follow you as they'd often get stuck. Also, my mouse occasionally flashed on the right hand side of the screen. Other than these minor bugs, however, I'd say this game is worth buying.

42173747.review:
Half-Life: Opposing Force is a first person sci-fi shooter game developed by Gearbox Software for the GoldSrc engine. It follows the misadventures of Adrian Shephard, a military goon turned Gordon Freeman-esque action hero after getting sent in to neutralize the events of the original Half-Life.

A solid campaign and thrilling techno score will probably be the most engaging parts of this product, although the original game still had both. The new editions to the mix aren't considerably interesting, and a few of the added monsters are more frustrating than enjoyable. I thought the final boss was pretty interesting looking but critically easy to fight and not particularly interesting gameplay-wise. The new perspective, that is, a soldier, doesn't really contribute much with anything. I was hoping to see some ally soldiers who would fight alongside me, and although I did find a few, they were largely pointless, dying as easily as the security guards from Half-Life 1. Ultimately, this product just feels pointless, even if it does provide more of the quintessential Half-Life experience.

Plot-wise, this game is fairly barren as well. If you can't get enough of the G-Man, perhaps just look up his final speech on youtube, because although it is a creepy and enjoyable speech, it isn't enough. The only context in which I'd recommend this game is if you can't get enough of the original Half-Life flavor in your noggin. Fortunately for Gearbox, a lot of people can't, and neither could I.

As it is, it's a tough-as-nails corridor shooter with aggressive ai and a pretty well utilized score. More than enough to recommend it, but not exactly with flying colors. I wish I could say it was imperitive to the Half-Life sandwich, but this dressing is more of a side.

Half Life Opposing Force is a side story where you play as Shepard, a high ranking officer sent into Black Mesa to rescue scientists but have your chopper shot down by Zen aircraft. 

The story for Opposing Force is nothing to write home about as it's more shallow than Half Life 2's :Lost Coast level. However it's excusable as the gameplay is what holds it together. Compared to the original Half Life. Opposing Force adds more ways for units that tag along with you to help out, and it also adds more weapons to use. You will still be at home with the fast Half Life gameplay but now with LMG's and some new Zen weapons that add to the momentum based combat. It also adds more enemy Archetypes to fight against later in the game that require you to think some of your movements out a little more instead of just b-hopping everywhere. It's nothing that stands out too much but is a good play through if you already enjoyed Half Life 1's mechanics but wanted more Black Mesa and less Zen.

41760054.review:
HalfLife Opposing Force brings the has much action and problem solving challenges as HalfLife, but if you're a fan of HalfLife then you'll enjoy being on the other side of the story, and find the exquisite moments where both storylines touch very entertaining. The fact that you're a marine, does bring more group effort, when you join your fellow marines against the black ops teams or alien invaders, something that you did little on HalfLife. 
After playing HalfLife Blueshit, I was not expecting a full lenght game, so I was suprised when the Opposing Force took much longer to finish.
Being a Mac user, I did bumped into the nasty final boss programming bug, where the Gene Worm disappears, and you were not teleported out of the room. This is a known bug since at least 2013, so it could have been fixed by Valve already.
Overall, for a HalfLife fan, this was very entertaining, at the same level of expectations as HalfLife.

41723887.review:
Half Life: Opposing Force is one of the worst FPS games I have ever played. It's an overpraised, watered down, boring, frustrating downgrade of Half Life, a game which is already a mixed bag.

Story:

half life but u r solder. That's it. It might as well be a level pack for Half Life. 

AI:

Annoying. It's good, but annoying. Nothing much to say there.

Weapons:

The old weapons are not worth mentioning, so I won't, but I will talk about the new ones. The melee weapons are just the crowbar, but fast or slow. The Barnacle is cool, but underused. The Desert Eagle is basically the Magnum but better. The SAW Machine Gun is basically the Machine Gun but better. The Sniper Rifle is cool, but underused. The Spore Launcher is cool, but underused. The Shock Roach is really cool. So is the Displacer Cannon. Overall, they're almost all similar to other weapons or underused. Again, might as well just be a level pack for Half Life.

Enemies: 

Again, the old ones aren't worth mentioning, so I'll only talk about the new ones. They can all die in a fucking hole. The Pit Drones are bullet sponges. They're just there to get rid of ammo. The Shock Troopers are also there to get rid of ammo, but also there to get rid of health. Vortigores are also there to get rid of ammo and health, but are 10 times more annoying. The boss enemies are basically just the tentacles monsters from Blast Pit. It seems like everything in this game that's "new" is just copies of older things.

Level Design:

Remember those puzzles that were impossible without a guide? Remember those "Where the fuck do I go?" moments? Imagine a game where those happened every time you killed a group of enemies. That game you just imagined is basically Half Life: Opposing Force.

Conclusion:

That's everything new. It all fucking sucks. if ya didnt notice, im bad at conclusions.

41629291.review:
This "Extension Pack" adds a lot to the half-life universe,
and I really think that it is an interesting idea to play from the 'bad guys' perspective!
if you are wondering if you should buy this Extension Pack, I would say yes and here are some reasons why you should:

Weapons almost perfectly one (9/10)
- This extension pack adds lots of new weapons that are fun to use!
- The textures, sounds, and model make the weapons look and feel extra good!
- I really wish they had these weapons in the original Half-Life or in future Half-Life games.

Puzzles are not too difficult nor simple (9/10)
- The puzzles in this game are challenging but not going too far!
- They are a big part of the game, and they where made very well!

Atmosphere awesome like in the first game (9/10)
- I really liked the style and feel of this game!
- The textures, sounds and maps are well put together,
nothing seems out of place!

Enemies/NPCs are very interesting (8/10)
- This game adds really cool new Enemies and NPCs!
- The new enemies are challenging and are a refresh to the gameplay!
- The new NPCs are awesome and fun to interact with!
basically another refresher for the gameplay!

Sounds are well designed (8/10)
- Even the new sounds are really good and high quality for it's time.
- This game's sounds are easily recognizable which is a good thing!

Gameplay is awesome (8/10)
- I really like the movement in this game! (for new players it would not be the most comfortable system)
- I really liked also the rope claiming thingy they added
- And I enjoyed going through the Boot Camp (The Tutorial)
- The paste of this game is hella fun!
- The new enemies, weapons and features are really made well!

Textures are well made for their time (7/10)
- This game's graphics are not the photorealistic graphics of today, but even today the look nice and have a really nice 'atmosphere' in them.
- Even the newer graphics that this extension pack added don't look out of place, well done!

AI is smart and enjoyable (7/10)
- Sometimes the AI feels a bit too strong and at times too weak.
- The enemies take cover and try to hide when hurt.
- NPCs know when to take risks and when its too much for them.
- The enemy AI is challenging and really well made!

Thank you for reading my review!
My final score for this Extension Pack would be a solid (8/10)

41161130.review:
The box smashing simulator for military personnel '99....



Now, when I got your attention, let's write a proper review. It is my very first one, so please be kind to me :D 

Simply a great addition to Half-Life franchise with good story. The look from the other side of the conflict is something what should be interesting, right? It is, however in the end you just basically fight for your life against alliens and black-ops, but the atmosphere of catching Freeeman is still there, which is great. Gameplay is good (I thought the campaign was longer, but I have finished it under 6 hours), we have a bunch of new weapons with pretty neat functions (that desert eagle with laser sights is my favourite and machine gun with its kickback is crazy), alien weapons are good too, level architecture is really nice and we have a few new enemies and bosses. Lot of new atractive enviroments - biodomes, testing areas, biolabs, exteriors in desert and even the training mission was fun. However this is great game, im still faving fun playing after nearly 19 years.

A classic example of an "Expansion" that tells a satisfying side story of a Marine during the events of the original Half Life. the game has a slightly different feel but still Expands on the story and gameplay, with new weapons and enemies to face while you are traped in Black Mesa. You play as a H.E.C.U Marine named Adrian Shepard as he is tasked with eliminating "Xen" invaders and everything else in the facility but before he even makes it to the landing zone him and his sqaud are shot out of the sky leaving Adrian as the last survivor. through out the game you will be pushed to your limits with the games difficulty and interesting level design making you have to adapt and strategize to progress to the next level while building your arsenal of new weapons that fit the style of the game.
