41075960.review:
Opposing Force is a great example why I will always prefer the expansion pack method of adding content to a game over DLC or micro transactions. This game is arguably even better than the original Half-Life in a lot of aspects and in any discussion about Half-Life you will have people who will list this as their all time favorite Half-Life game. It's for a good reason obviously considering how much the game expands upon the formula and mechanics of the first Half-Life. 

The game introduces a ton of new content in all aspects. You have a new alien faction known as "race-x" that ramps up the difficulty and challenge in the game a ton and in general this game is quite a bit harder than the original Half-Life so I recommend playing it AFTER you complete the original Half-Life, while the game starts out with just normal Xen enemies once the race-x dudes start showing up you are going to realize how dangerous things have gotten when your trapped in a sewer with the big race-x dudes who shoot giant fucking death balls at you that can kill instantly if you are in the direct way of the ball. The game also expands upon the "black-ops" by making them a separate faction from HECU and adding appropriate units to replace what would be marine enemies in the original Half-Life. There is also a great number of more companians available to the player including medic's which in addition to being capable of firing back at the enemy also can heal the player and other friendly units, you have engineers who can cut through doors with their blow torch, and of course just normal grunts who dont have any special ability's per say but usually come with a pretty good weapon like a shotgun or assault rifle. You also have a new security guard in addition to your normal Barney's who's called "Otis" and he is a pretty amusing and interesting character to have and, again, spices up the content by adding more variety. 

The arsenal the player is capable of carrying has been drastically expanded upon including two different melee weapons in place of half-life 1's single melee weapon and multiple alien and experimental weapons. A big stand out to me was the teleporter gun which can one hit "kill" an enemy by essentially teleporting him to a random location presumably somewhere in Xen, but the secondary fire will teleport you yourself to a random location in Xen that can only be accessed in that way and often contains many resources and a teleport on the other side which will get you back into black mesa at a fixed position that is usually later in the level, which is interesting because it essentially allows you to skip whole parts of levels as long as you have the ammo to utilize the alt-fire. There is also a barnacle weapon which the player can use to grapple across gaps and walls at points as well as latch on to enemies and pull it into its maw which the barnacle will proceed to devour, really creative and diverse weapons loadout for sure. 

The story adds a lot of interesting new lore to the Half-Life story besides just a new alien race by clarifying on the relationship between the soldiers and the black-ops and a pretty disturbing plot point of what happens to the marines who fail to evacuate or are left behind after the order to pull out comes out. It also expands on the character of the G-man giving new insight into his "personality" and actions as well as expanding on the ending to half-life by showing what happens to black mesa itself after everything is said and done. 

The multiplayer has also been expanded upon with many maps and game-modes that the original Half-Life simply does not have. 

The only bad part of playing this thing is after playing such an awesome game your going to be tempted to recall the current state of gearbox software and feel a bit of despair at the whole thing. Its like if somebody who you like and highly respected joined a skinhead gang, became a gay prostitute and contracted aids and than went around snorting cocaine and beating up homeless people and stray dogs and puppy's before shooting up an old folks home before blowing himself up and screaming "hail Satan" as his last words. Maybe a bit dramatic but seriously dude, what a fall from grace.

41005373.review:
[b]+[/b] When I play this game, I feel like playing a familiar game with an entirely fresh experience. Immersive, interactive, destructive, physically correct, and grotesquely violent, [i]Opposing Force[/i] ensures a quality game of [i]Half-Life[/i] as a reality.
[b]+[/b] Gordon could break boxes with the crowbar, but Adrian Shephard can turn Headcrabs (amongst other small creatures) into a splat of guts with the powerful strike of a wrench. The player gets a thorough story of a tale of one soldier of the Opposing Force who finds himself to be fighting for survival, and while the secondary characters that tell the dialogue are still designed to be "there and done", the exchange of conversation and dialogue has notably been improved.
[b]+[/b] Graphics are equally beautiful as the original, and the level design is agreeable and additionally, thanks to the utilization of some of the additions of new content, has some of the trickiest and most well-planned level architectures and puzzles ever.
[b]+[/b] For an expansion pack, we got an abundance of new weapons (up to 23 according to the game files and in multiplayer compared to the original's 14--with 5 being entirely new weapons and 4 essentially being re-editions--though there are only 17 in single-player), enemies, personnel with their own abilities for helping the player, and ways of physically interacting with the world, notably the climbing of ropes, which I find to be among the most pleasing additions to the game. Gearbox obviously tried so hard to make the game not feel too familiar to the original that they would add the new stuff and replace some content with better versions. The Barnacle as a weapon is a very special surprise to me, we have teleporting guns, there are replacements such as the revolver being placed by the more-functional Desert Eagle, and we are fighting primarily against a race of aliens known as Race X, comprising species other than those in the original game, not to mention that the flashlight has been replaced by night vision.
[b]+[/b] As a bonus for enthusiasts of multiplayer, functionality is expanded to not only include Deathmatch as in the original [i]Half-Life[/i] as well as additional levels, but Capture the Flag as well.
[b]-[/b] Sadly, there are cases where there are under-demonstrations of the improvements such as the ropes as well as over-demonstration of certain improvements at a time that can render the game a bit repetitive, specifically late in it. I have had a lot of fun with the improvements, but with about 7 hours of campaign, I am left disappointed with the feeling of missing out on the full potential.

[b]CONCLUSION:[/b] [i]Half-Life: Opposing Force[/i] offers ideas that further demonstrate the capabilities of the GoldSrc engine and successfully build on the original game, in the same way that made the original popular to begin with.

[b]SCORE: 90%[/b]

40808049.review:
[b]Half-Life: Opposing Force[/b] is an expansion of the original [b]Half-Life[/b]. It allows you to witness the events of the first game through the eyes of Corporal Shephard, one of the marines who were sent to hunt down Gordon Freeman. It provides you with more weapons than the original game, including (but not only): a sniper rifle, an improved pistol, a grappling gun and a teleportation gun. The enemies you face are: black ops (including those pesky, superfast sniper girls) and the aliens (both new and old ones). [b]Opposing Force[/b] also introduces some new mechanics like: rope climbing and squad control. There is only a few times when you can use your squad members, but when you can, they provide assisstance in firefights, can cut through metal doors and heal you. Note: however, unlike Freeman, Shephard can't use the long jump module.

[b]Opposing Force[/b] had the potential to be a great expansion to a great game, but imo it's inferior to the original game in every aspect. It adds little to the original story, has confusing level design, boring and/or unintuitive puzzles and unbalanced enemies. [b]HF:OF[/b] relies heavily on surprise attacks and, it seems, that trial and error was the intended way to progress through this game. At times, there's too much platforming and not enough shooting. But when the shooting is there, it's against nearly impossible odds.

[b]HF:OF[/b] is nowhere near the smooth, gradual and intuitive experience the original game provided. That's why I can't recommend it. Unless you want to cheat through this game for the tiny bits of extra story that it provides OR really enjoy punishing hardcore shooters, just skip to [b]HF2[/b].

[b]My overall rating:[/b] [u]5/10.[/u]

40564274.review:
A great example of how expansions (or DLC) should be made!

Opposing Force managed to differentiate itself just enough from the original Half-Life, while remaining fun and non-repetitive.

The story was quite interesting, as you take the role of Corporal Shephard, a military specialist assigned to eliminate Gordon Freeman, after the initial events of the first game.

During his mission you encounter a big variety of enemies, both human and alien. The aliens especially were quite many.
As usual, the G-Man made a few cameo appearances as well, while observing and evaluating you.

Many new weapons were included too and particularly the alien ones were a nice innovation from the original game and made you truly feel how it is to play on the alien side (a few years before Halo successfully did it, too).

Aside from the added enemies and weapons, new allies came along too: the medic and the engineer, which could respectively heal you in battle and enable you to access new areas. This was another nice addition, from the allies of the original that could only follow you and assist you for a bit.

The length was also good enough for an expansion, about half the duration of Half-Life (duh).
Revisiting Xen was nice too.

All in all, Opposing Force was a good nostalgia trip, on the trail of what made the first game great.
Recommended definitely!

40173029.review:
Oh, my, f/cking, lord, THIS WAS F/CKING FABULOUS. It brings so many brilliant new touches to the Half Life series. You have new weapons: the Desert Eagle, the Detached Barnacle (which sort of works as a grappling hook), the Heavy Machine Gun, the Sniper Rifle, the Shock Roach etc. Not to mention some other great new additions too: night vision goggles instead of a flashlight, the capability of climbing up ropes as well as swinging from one to the other and the new enemies: the Shock Troopers, the Pit Drones, the Male Assassins, the Voltigores etc. 

Each level is more exhilirating than the previous. Before I'm fighting a few Shock Troopers, afterwards I'm running for my life in a tunnel full of raging Voltigores. The Portal Launcher is a great scientific weapon, and to me the most fascinating. Causing decent damage if aimed well, but unlike with the Gluon Gun and the Tau Cannon I found that it wasn't too handy combat wise, but came instead to more use in terms of support. Its alt fire teleports you to a part of the Xen world, each with either healing pools, supplies from fallen HEV scientists or both which I found to be incredible, as well as being teleported to a different environment each time. However, the alt fire requires 60 or more power. 

There are 2 boss fights in this marvel of a game, both of which are great fun and not too frustrating. Also, I loved how the training room had a military boot camp setting, and I recommend you play the training room since it truly is spectacular and teaches you some of the new features such as rope swinging. This game SERIOUSLY brings a wide array of new wonders to the table, this is a must play, I repeat, this is a MUST PLAY GO GET IT NOW.

Opposing Force is well done, but if I may make one negative remark, the final boss battle is unfortunately both repetitive and anticlimatic, lacking in a sense of danger/engagement.

39143785.review:
Half-Life: Opposing Force was an really good entry to the Half-Life universe. Taking place during the original Half-Life, you play as Corpral Adrian Shepard. You are sent to Black Mesa on an unknown mission. However, the mission isn't important anymore as you have to escape the facility after you crash right into an alien invasion.

To start off, the concept of focusing on the opposite side of the protagonist is very interesting, and I liked that. The gameplay itself is the same as the original, just shooting a lot of enemies, and solving puzzles. In this game you get a variety of new weapons (though some of them are pretty much the same, even if they are "new"). Weapons that stood out to me was the sniper-rifle, some weird alien fish that shoots acidic slimeballs (which your character pets for some reason), and you can even use the alien Barnicle to use as a grappling hook or use it to eat a target. 

Though these weapons can be seen as overpowered, one complaint I had with this game is the ridiciously more overpowered new enemies introduced into this game. You have a giant alien that shoots a powerful 1 hit ko attack, oh, and these things hang out in groups too, so good luck fighting them. I played this game on easy and it was still stupidly difficult for no reason at all.

Overall, though I had some pretty tough rage-inducing moments, I still enjoyed the game a lot. From the new weapons, and the story, also some callbacks to the original game. These I think really do weigh down the major complaint I had with the game, the overpowered enemies. I would give HL:OF, a 6.5/10. I recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed the first Half-Life game.

38861713.review:
The game itself is fun if you ignore everything about the fact that it's Half-Life, and play it solely for the action.
However, even that has its drawbacks.
While, yes, it was published in 1999, there are glitches within the game that are so frustratingly obvious to the developers that it makes me question as to whether or not they actually bothered to give the game a run through to find and fix these glitches.
One of the many I've encountered is just a literal 'Getting stuck' glitch. You'll get on an elevator, activate it, and the elevator simply won't move because your body has frozen in place and is stopping it from being able to, y'know, BE AN ELEVATOR.
Another is where you'll die randomly when activating certain machinery, such as the Star-Wars; A New Hope garbage compactor rip off, where upon activating it, if you try to move, you will just...Die. Out of the blue. 

The lore as well, is an absolute insult to the Half-Life series. While Half-Life: Blueshift kept promise and stayed true to the series (But was disappointingly short), Opposing Force chooses to just throw in another batch of aliens into the mix. They are used as both the main 'Opposing force' to Opposing Force. The normal Xen aliens were practically thrown out the window, and are seldom used after the first few chapters (Minus headcrabs, Zombies and five Vortigaunts). 

You'd believe that these new enemies would include the Black Mesa personnel that are terrified of being butchered by highly trained Marines who have difficulty spelling, right?

Nope.

The game has ALL of the facility staff that you meet as friendly as possible, all practically running around naked, and none of the scientists even bothering to wear a Hazardous Environment Suit (Which must have been very well available due to how many bodies of dead HEV Scientists you find within Xen) and attempting to fight you and your men. 

What could you possibly replace the HECU with as the main human enemy within this horrid game?
Black Ops.
You read that right.
Black ops.

When originally, the Black Ops had only females whose relations with the HECU were unknown; Male Black Ops were added, practically being HECU that attack the HECU. Do they work as an Antagonist? Yes, they do, very well. However it simply doesn't make sense.

The HECU are advanced trained Marines that were sent into Black Mesa as a cleanup crew; The fact that they thought that  once a group as experienced as the HECU were unable to complete their job, that instead of just sending in another HECU Team to plant a nuke and extract, that they send in Black Ops to eliminate every NON-EXTRACTED HECU within Black Mesa, alongside all scientists, security officers and Aliens (Mind you, who ultimately fail at even successfully activating the bomb without the Gmans interference) is just retarded.

All in all;
It's a 'fun' action game with frustrating glitches and a horribly written story. Even the final boss fight is horrible.
My disappointment is immeasureable and my day is ruined.

To be honest, I quite frankly favor this game more than I do the original Half-Life (But I still hold the original game and entire franchise itself close to my heart despite how late I am getting into the series)

For starters, I'd say the game was definitely worth my 5 dollars, and it's such a treat to see a gem like this still thrive to this day. 

Yeah, I died /a lot/ in this game, and that's most likely because I suck at video games in the first place. But despite this, I beat it, enjoyed the game a lot and absolutely loved the take on the story from Adrian's point of view. 

As for the game itself, gameplay wise, again, I died a lot, despite playing on easy, and again this is probably because I suck. But then again, I wish it'd was a bit easier for something like the easy mode? Most of the time the game was simple,  but there were spots where I absolutely was being crowded by Pit Drones.

I'd say that the GoldSrc engine was definitely pushed to the limit when it came to effects, mobs, etc., and despite how old the graphics and textures are, you have to admit, the game is well done, just like the original game. 

I'm shit at reviewing games, however, one thing I can definitely say is: HLOF is really good, and if you're looking for more HL content, I'd suggest this expansion pack, along with Blue Shift, etc. 

P.S. Happy 18th Anniversary Opposing Force!

36587743.review:
Half-Life: Opposing Force, the first expansion of Half-Life. The single concept is already interesting on its own because we experience the great Black Mesa incident from who is supposed to be the enemy of Gordon Freeman. In addition to that the game has several new elements that make this expansion a fresh experience. Let's see what Opposing Force has to offer.


[h1][i][PLOT][/i][/h1]

The protagonist, Adrian Shephard, is someone who was sent to fulfill a mission that any other soldier could have done. However, he ended up doing something much bigger, something that had an impact on the future of the whole world. I don't know if it would have been for better or worse but the sequel, Half-Life 2, would have been completely different if Shephard had failed. Personally I would have liked to know more about him in the sequels but unfortunately Valve never developed the character any further. And since it's very unlikely that Valve'll release a new Half-Life game in the future things will probably stay that way.


[h1][i][GAMEPLAY][/i][/h1]

The gameplay is practically the same as the first Half-Life. The movement, the weapons, the enemies, everything is great, fluid and responsive. In addition to this there are new cool weapons, both of military and alien origin. New enemies, the Race X, which is are completely unrelated to the Xen creatures, and that add a new feeling and pacing to the game. Opposing Force is not a copy of the first game, it's an original adventure located at the same time as it is.


[h1][i][VISUALS][/i][/h1]

The same as the first game, although with a slightly greater amount of details. The graphics for its time were pretty good. The FPS' were still developing aesthetically and Half-Life was a step forward without a doubt. It's obvious that by today's standards it isn't impressive. However, for me the visuals of this game are a classic, a stamp that was won over the years product of the nostalgia of players like me.


[h1][i][MUSIC & SOUND][/i][/h1]

It's the same as the original game so it inherits all the good elements of it, although new material is needed. It seems to me they just reused SFX and music of the original game. It's good to hear the anazing music of the original game again, but I would also have liked to hear something new.


In conclusion, Half-Life: Opposing Force is an incredible expansion. It inherits all the good elements of the original game and expands upon it. I recommend you to play this if you loved the original game, like me!

My rating is:  [b]8.5 / Excellent.[/b]

An excellent expansion pack from developer Gearbox! I wonder how many of us still know what expansions were... nowadays these extra stories would come in the form of DLCs not an expansion pack. It meant to indicate a longer story and this is definitely a bigger pack than a dlc which can be a single weapon or a new costume for a character in the game.

In any case, Opposing Force puts us in the shoes of a corporal, a certain Adrian Shepard, who - along with his fellow soldiers - is sent to neutralise the enemies invading the Black Mesa facility. As expected, things go awry and you are alone facing the good-old aliens.

This is the best add on to Half-Life in my opinion. There are new weapons and not a single crowbar. You can also create a time paradox. Race X creatures are really good enemies and the gene worm is a lot more threatening than a gargantua and a PCV suit instead of an HEV suit or an armour vest. You get to interact with other soldiers and maybe even create a small group. I really have nothing negative to say about this, everything works well. Get this if you like Half-Life series!

By the way: the game comes with widescreen settings and vsync can be switched on! Just excellent!

35257750.review:
[h1] Nice expansion to a fantastic game. [/h1]

It was really cool seeing the Opposing Force's POV from HL1. I have always wished more modern games released expansions like this one, as it adds a lot of depth and detail into the game's universe. New environments and weapons were certainly enjoyable (especially the sniper rifle).This game does NOT stand on it's own though, play it directly after HL1.

[h1] 8.5/10 [/h1]

35049653.review:
The unseen part of Half life 1, must play for every half life fan.

Pros:

-Amazing new Weapons (lots of them)
-Amazing take on the opposing side of half life 1
-Awesome Squad mechanics
-Gordon freeman references
-G man cameos
-Unique storyline
-Explains Half Life 1
-More info into the half life lore
-Great new mechanics
-Pretty good boss fight
-Good enough length
-New Enemies

Cons:
-Sometimes frustating
-Bad Platforming

its a must play just play it, if you can't have enough of half life 1, try this and you wont be dissapointed.

35017120.review:
This game is a very well rounded expansion to the very first Half Life.
It shows new enemies, new weapons, and from another point of view.
I would recommend this game, and he is much more harder than Half Life 1.
Multiplayer is dead. You'll hardly find servers with active players.
My personal enjoyment : 10 out of 10.

35002738.review: This expansion is a nice complement to Half-Life.  You play as the soldiers who were sent to Black-Mesa and it shows what happened to them after Freeman left to Xen.  You get to fight new tougher aliens, use stronger weapons, and gain help from fellow soldiers.  The pacing is great and you'll have fun while returning to Black Mesa.

34994188.review: Amazing game, perfectly embed with the first Half-Life's story. Always great level design. There are a few bugs sometimes (like in the sewers in Foxtrot Uniform's chapter) but it's still playable till the end.
